malloc.c

1 /*
2  This is a version (aka dlmalloc) of malloc/free/realloc written by
3  Doug Lea and released to the public domain, as explained at
4  http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/ Send questions,
5  comments, complaints, performance data, etc to dl@cs.oswego.edu
6 
7 * Version 2.8.6 Wed Aug 29 06:57:58 2012 Doug Lea
8  Note: There may be an updated version of this malloc obtainable at
9  ftp://gee.cs.oswego.edu/pub/misc/malloc.c
10  Check before installing!
11 
12 * Quickstart
13 
14  This library is all in one file to simplify the most common usage:
15  ftp it, compile it (-O3), and link it into another program. All of
16  the compile-time options default to reasonable values for use on
17  most platforms. You might later want to step through various
18  compile-time and dynamic tuning options.
19 
20  For convenience, an include file for code using this malloc is at:
21  ftp://gee.cs.oswego.edu/pub/misc/malloc-2.8.6.h
22  You don't really need this .h file unless you call functions not
23  defined in your system include files. The .h file contains only the
24  excerpts from this file needed for using this malloc on ANSI C/C++
25  systems, so long as you haven't changed compile-time options about
26  naming and tuning parameters. If you do, then you can create your
27  own malloc.h that does include all settings by cutting at the point
28  indicated below. Note that you may already by default be using a C
29  library containing a malloc that is based on some version of this
30  malloc (for example in linux). You might still want to use the one
31  in this file to customize settings or to avoid overheads associated
32  with library versions.
33 
34 * Vital statistics:
35 
36  Supported pointer/size_t representation: 4 or 8 bytes
37  size_t MUST be an unsigned type of the same width as
38  pointers. (If you are using an ancient system that declares
39  size_t as a signed type, or need it to be a different width
40  than pointers, you can use a previous release of this malloc
41  (e.g. 2.7.2) supporting these.)
42 
43  Alignment: 8 bytes (minimum)
44  This suffices for nearly all current machines and C compilers.
45  However, you can define MALLOC_ALIGNMENT to be wider than this
46  if necessary (up to 128bytes), at the expense of using more space.
47 
48  Minimum overhead per allocated chunk: 4 or 8 bytes (if 4byte sizes)
49  8 or 16 bytes (if 8byte sizes)
50  Each malloced chunk has a hidden word of overhead holding size
51  and status information, and additional cross-check word
52  if FOOTERS is defined.
53 
54  Minimum allocated size: 4-byte ptrs: 16 bytes (including overhead)
55  8-byte ptrs: 32 bytes (including overhead)
56 
57  Even a request for zero bytes (i.e., malloc(0)) returns a
58  pointer to something of the minimum allocatable size.
59  The maximum overhead wastage (i.e., number of extra bytes
60  allocated than were requested in malloc) is less than or equal
61  to the minimum size, except for requests >= mmap_threshold that
62  are serviced via mmap(), where the worst case wastage is about
63  32 bytes plus the remainder from a system page (the minimal
64  mmap unit); typically 4096 or 8192 bytes.
65 
66  Security: static-safe; optionally more or less
67  The "security" of malloc refers to the ability of malicious
68  code to accentuate the effects of errors (for example, freeing
69  space that is not currently malloc'ed or overwriting past the
70  ends of chunks) in code that calls malloc. This malloc
71  guarantees not to modify any memory locations below the base of
72  heap, i.e., static variables, even in the presence of usage
73  errors. The routines additionally detect most improper frees
74  and reallocs. All this holds as long as the static bookkeeping
75  for malloc itself is not corrupted by some other means. This
76  is only one aspect of security -- these checks do not, and
77  cannot, detect all possible programming errors.
78 
79  If FOOTERS is defined nonzero, then each allocated chunk
80  carries an additional check word to verify that it was malloced
81  from its space. These check words are the same within each
82  execution of a program using malloc, but differ across
83  executions, so externally crafted fake chunks cannot be
84  freed. This improves security by rejecting frees/reallocs that
85  could corrupt heap memory, in addition to the checks preventing
86  writes to statics that are always on. This may further improve
87  security at the expense of time and space overhead. (Note that
88  FOOTERS may also be worth using with MSPACES.)
89 
90  By default detected errors cause the program to abort (calling
91  "abort()"). You can override this to instead proceed past
92  errors by defining PROCEED_ON_ERROR. In this case, a bad free
93  has no effect, and a malloc that encounters a bad address
94  caused by user overwrites will ignore the bad address by
95  dropping pointers and indices to all known memory. This may
96  be appropriate for programs that should continue if at all
97  possible in the face of programming errors, although they may
98  run out of memory because dropped memory is never reclaimed.
99 
100  If you don't like either of these options, you can define
101  CORRUPTION_ERROR_ACTION and USAGE_ERROR_ACTION to do anything
102  else. And if if you are sure that your program using malloc has
103  no errors or vulnerabilities, you can define INSECURE to 1,
104  which might (or might not) provide a small performance improvement.
105 
106  It is also possible to limit the maximum total allocatable
107  space, using malloc_set_footprint_limit. This is not
108  designed as a security feature in itself (calls to set limits
109  are not screened or privileged), but may be useful as one
110  aspect of a secure implementation.
111 
112  Thread-safety: NOT thread-safe unless USE_LOCKS defined non-zero
113  When USE_LOCKS is defined, each public call to malloc, free,
114  etc is surrounded with a lock. By default, this uses a plain
115  pthread mutex, win32 critical section, or a spin-lock if if
116  available for the platform and not disabled by setting
117  USE_SPIN_LOCKS=0. However, if USE_RECURSIVE_LOCKS is defined,
118  recursive versions are used instead (which are not required for
119  base functionality but may be needed in layered extensions).
120  Using a global lock is not especially fast, and can be a major
121  bottleneck. It is designed only to provide minimal protection
122  in concurrent environments, and to provide a basis for
123  extensions. If you are using malloc in a concurrent program,
124  consider instead using nedmalloc
125  (http://www.nedprod.com/programs/portable/nedmalloc/) or
126  ptmalloc (See http://www.malloc.de), which are derived from
127  versions of this malloc.
128 
129  System requirements: Any combination of MORECORE and/or MMAP/MUNMAP
130  This malloc can use unix sbrk or any emulation (invoked using
131  the CALL_MORECORE macro) and/or mmap/munmap or any emulation
132  (invoked using CALL_MMAP/CALL_MUNMAP) to get and release system
133  memory. On most unix systems, it tends to work best if both
134  MORECORE and MMAP are enabled. On Win32, it uses emulations
135  based on VirtualAlloc. It also uses common C library functions
136  like memset.
137 
138  Compliance: I believe it is compliant with the Single Unix Specification
139  (See http://www.unix.org). Also SVID/XPG, ANSI C, and probably
140  others as well.
141 
142 * Overview of algorithms
143 
144  This is not the fastest, most space-conserving, most portable, or
145  most tunable malloc ever written. However it is among the fastest
146  while also being among the most space-conserving, portable and
147  tunable. Consistent balance across these factors results in a good
148  general-purpose allocator for malloc-intensive programs.
149 
150  In most ways, this malloc is a best-fit allocator. Generally, it
151  chooses the best-fitting existing chunk for a request, with ties
152  broken in approximately least-recently-used order. (This strategy
153  normally maintains low fragmentation.) However, for requests less
154  than 256bytes, it deviates from best-fit when there is not an
155  exactly fitting available chunk by preferring to use space adjacent
156  to that used for the previous small request, as well as by breaking
157  ties in approximately most-recently-used order. (These enhance
158  locality of series of small allocations.) And for very large requests
159  (>= 256Kb by default), it relies on system memory mapping
160  facilities, if supported. (This helps avoid carrying around and
161  possibly fragmenting memory used only for large chunks.)
162 
163  All operations (except malloc_stats and mallinfo) have execution
164  times that are bounded by a constant factor of the number of bits in
165  a size_t, not counting any clearing in calloc or copying in realloc,
166  or actions surrounding MORECORE and MMAP that have times
167  proportional to the number of non-contiguous regions returned by
168  system allocation routines, which is often just 1. In real-time
169  applications, you can optionally suppress segment traversals using
170  NO_SEGMENT_TRAVERSAL, which assures bounded execution even when
171  system allocators return non-contiguous spaces, at the typical
172  expense of carrying around more memory and increased fragmentation.
173 
174  The implementation is not very modular and seriously overuses
175  macros. Perhaps someday all C compilers will do as good a job
176  inlining modular code as can now be done by brute-force expansion,
177  but now, enough of them seem not to.
178 
179  Some compilers issue a lot of warnings about code that is
180  dead/unreachable only on some platforms, and also about intentional
181  uses of negation on unsigned types. All known cases of each can be
182  ignored.
183 
184  For a longer but out of date high-level description, see
185  http://gee.cs.oswego.edu/dl/html/malloc.html
186 
187 * MSPACES
188  If MSPACES is defined, then in addition to malloc, free, etc.,
189  this file also defines mspace_malloc, mspace_free, etc. These
190  are versions of malloc routines that take an "mspace" argument
191  obtained using create_mspace, to control all internal bookkeeping.
192  If ONLY_MSPACES is defined, only these versions are compiled.
193  So if you would like to use this allocator for only some allocations,
194  and your system malloc for others, you can compile with
195  ONLY_MSPACES and then do something like...
196  static mspace mymspace = create_mspace(0,0); // for example
197  #define mymalloc(bytes) mspace_malloc(mymspace, bytes)
198 
199  (Note: If you only need one instance of an mspace, you can instead
200  use "USE_DL_PREFIX" to relabel the global malloc.)
201 
202  You can similarly create thread-local allocators by storing
203  mspaces as thread-locals. For example:
204  static __thread mspace tlms = 0;
205  void* tlmalloc(size_t bytes) {
206  if (tlms == 0) tlms = create_mspace(0, 0);
207  return mspace_malloc(tlms, bytes);
208  }
209  void tlfree(void* mem) { mspace_free(tlms, mem); }
210 
211  Unless FOOTERS is defined, each mspace is completely independent.
212  You cannot allocate from one and free to another (although
213  conformance is only weakly checked, so usage errors are not always
214  caught). If FOOTERS is defined, then each chunk carries around a tag
215  indicating its originating mspace, and frees are directed to their
216  originating spaces. Normally, this requires use of locks.
217 
218  ------------------------- Compile-time options ---------------------------
219 
220 Be careful in setting #define values for numerical constants of type
221 size_t. On some systems, literal values are not automatically extended
222 to size_t precision unless they are explicitly casted. You can also
223 use the symbolic values MAX_SIZE_T, SIZE_T_ONE, etc below.
224 
225 WIN32 default: defined if _WIN32 defined
226  Defining WIN32 sets up defaults for MS environment and compilers.
227  Otherwise defaults are for unix. Beware that there seem to be some
228  cases where this malloc might not be a pure drop-in replacement for
229  Win32 malloc: Random-looking failures from Win32 GDI API's (eg;
230  SetDIBits()) may be due to bugs in some video driver implementations
231  when pixel buffers are malloc()ed, and the region spans more than
232  one VirtualAlloc()ed region. Because dlmalloc uses a small (64Kb)
233  default granularity, pixel buffers may straddle virtual allocation
234  regions more often than when using the Microsoft allocator. You can
235  avoid this by using VirtualAlloc() and VirtualFree() for all pixel
236  buffers rather than using malloc(). If this is not possible,
237  recompile this malloc with a larger DEFAULT_GRANULARITY. Note:
238  in cases where MSC and gcc (cygwin) are known to differ on WIN32,
239  conditions use _MSC_VER to distinguish them.
240 
241 DLMALLOC_EXPORT default: extern
242  Defines how public APIs are declared. If you want to export via a
243  Windows DLL, you might define this as
244  #define DLMALLOC_EXPORT extern __declspec(dllexport)
245  If you want a POSIX ELF shared object, you might use
246  #define DLMALLOC_EXPORT extern __attribute__((visibility("default")))
247 
248 MALLOC_ALIGNMENT default: (size_t)(2 * sizeof(void *))
249  Controls the minimum alignment for malloc'ed chunks. It must be a
250  power of two and at least 8, even on machines for which smaller
251  alignments would suffice. It may be defined as larger than this
252  though. Note however that code and data structures are optimized for
253  the case of 8-byte alignment.
254 
255 MSPACES default: 0 (false)
256  If true, compile in support for independent allocation spaces.
257  This is only supported if HAVE_MMAP is true.
258 
259 ONLY_MSPACES default: 0 (false)
260  If true, only compile in mspace versions, not regular versions.
261 
262 USE_LOCKS default: 0 (false)
263  Causes each call to each public routine to be surrounded with
264  pthread or WIN32 mutex lock/unlock. (If set true, this can be
265  overridden on a per-mspace basis for mspace versions.) If set to a
266  non-zero value other than 1, locks are used, but their
267  implementation is left out, so lock functions must be supplied manually,
268  as described below.
269 
270 USE_SPIN_LOCKS default: 1 iff USE_LOCKS and spin locks available
271  If true, uses custom spin locks for locking. This is currently
272  supported only gcc >= 4.1, older gccs on x86 platforms, and recent
273  MS compilers. Otherwise, posix locks or win32 critical sections are
274  used.
275 
276 USE_RECURSIVE_LOCKS default: not defined
277  If defined nonzero, uses recursive (aka reentrant) locks, otherwise
278  uses plain mutexes. This is not required for malloc proper, but may
279  be needed for layered allocators such as nedmalloc.
280 
281 LOCK_AT_FORK default: not defined
282  If defined nonzero, performs pthread_atfork upon initialization
283  to initialize child lock while holding parent lock. The implementation
284  assumes that pthread locks (not custom locks) are being used. In other
285  cases, you may need to customize the implementation.
286 
287 FOOTERS default: 0
288  If true, provide extra checking and dispatching by placing
289  information in the footers of allocated chunks. This adds
290  space and time overhead.
291 
292 INSECURE default: 0
293  If true, omit checks for usage errors and heap space overwrites.
294 
295 USE_DL_PREFIX default: NOT defined
296  Causes compiler to prefix all public routines with the string 'dl'.
297  This can be useful when you only want to use this malloc in one part
298  of a program, using your regular system malloc elsewhere.
299 
300 MALLOC_INSPECT_ALL default: NOT defined
301  If defined, compiles malloc_inspect_all and mspace_inspect_all, that
302  perform traversal of all heap space. Unless access to these
303  functions is otherwise restricted, you probably do not want to
304  include them in secure implementations.
305 
306 ABORT default: defined as abort()
307  Defines how to abort on failed checks. On most systems, a failed
308  check cannot die with an "assert" or even print an informative
309  message, because the underlying print routines in turn call malloc,
310  which will fail again. Generally, the best policy is to simply call
311  abort(). It's not very useful to do more than this because many
312  errors due to overwriting will show up as address faults (null, odd
313  addresses etc) rather than malloc-triggered checks, so will also
314  abort. Also, most compilers know that abort() does not return, so
315  can better optimize code conditionally calling it.
316 
317 PROCEED_ON_ERROR default: defined as 0 (false)
318  Controls whether detected bad addresses cause them to bypassed
319  rather than aborting. If set, detected bad arguments to free and
320  realloc are ignored. And all bookkeeping information is zeroed out
321  upon a detected overwrite of freed heap space, thus losing the
322  ability to ever return it from malloc again, but enabling the
323  application to proceed. If PROCEED_ON_ERROR is defined, the
324  static variable malloc_corruption_error_count is compiled in
325  and can be examined to see if errors have occurred. This option
326  generates slower code than the default abort policy.
327 
328 DEBUG default: NOT defined
329  The DEBUG setting is mainly intended for people trying to modify
330  this code or diagnose problems when porting to new platforms.
331  However, it may also be able to better isolate user errors than just
332  using runtime checks. The assertions in the check routines spell
333  out in more detail the assumptions and invariants underlying the
334  algorithms. The checking is fairly extensive, and will slow down
335  execution noticeably. Calling malloc_stats or mallinfo with DEBUG
336  set will attempt to check every non-mmapped allocated and free chunk
337  in the course of computing the summaries.
338 
339 ABORT_ON_ASSERT_FAILURE default: defined as 1 (true)
340  Debugging assertion failures can be nearly impossible if your
341  version of the assert macro causes malloc to be called, which will
342  lead to a cascade of further failures, blowing the runtime stack.
343  ABORT_ON_ASSERT_FAILURE cause assertions failures to call abort(),
344  which will usually make debugging easier.
345 
346 MALLOC_FAILURE_ACTION default: sets errno to ENOMEM, or no-op on win32
347  The action to take before "return 0" when malloc fails to be able to
348  return memory because there is none available.
349 
350 HAVE_MORECORE default: 1 (true) unless win32 or ONLY_MSPACES
351  True if this system supports sbrk or an emulation of it.
352 
353 MORECORE default: sbrk
354  The name of the sbrk-style system routine to call to obtain more
355  memory. See below for guidance on writing custom MORECORE
356  functions. The type of the argument to sbrk/MORECORE varies across
357  systems. It cannot be size_t, because it supports negative
358  arguments, so it is normally the signed type of the same width as
359  size_t (sometimes declared as "intptr_t"). It doesn't much matter
360  though. Internally, we only call it with arguments less than half
361  the max value of a size_t, which should work across all reasonable
362  possibilities, although sometimes generating compiler warnings.
363 
364 MORECORE_CONTIGUOUS default: 1 (true) if HAVE_MORECORE
365  If true, take advantage of fact that consecutive calls to MORECORE
366  with positive arguments always return contiguous increasing
367  addresses. This is true of unix sbrk. It does not hurt too much to
368  set it true anyway, since malloc copes with non-contiguities.
369  Setting it false when definitely non-contiguous saves time
370  and possibly wasted space it would take to discover this though.
371 
372 MORECORE_CANNOT_TRIM default: NOT defined
373  True if MORECORE cannot release space back to the system when given
374  negative arguments. This is generally necessary only if you are
375  using a hand-crafted MORECORE function that cannot handle negative
376  arguments.
377 
378 NO_SEGMENT_TRAVERSAL default: 0
379  If non-zero, suppresses traversals of memory segments
380  returned by either MORECORE or CALL_MMAP. This disables
381  merging of segments that are contiguous, and selectively
382  releasing them to the OS if unused, but bounds execution times.
383 
384 HAVE_MMAP default: 1 (true)
385  True if this system supports mmap or an emulation of it. If so, and
386  HAVE_MORECORE is not true, MMAP is used for all system
387  allocation. If set and HAVE_MORECORE is true as well, MMAP is
388  primarily used to directly allocate very large blocks. It is also
389  used as a backup strategy in cases where MORECORE fails to provide
390  space from system. Note: A single call to MUNMAP is assumed to be
391  able to unmap memory that may have be allocated using multiple calls
392  to MMAP, so long as they are adjacent.
393 
394 HAVE_MREMAP default: 1 on linux, else 0
395  If true realloc() uses mremap() to re-allocate large blocks and
396  extend or shrink allocation spaces.
397 
398 MMAP_CLEARS default: 1 except on WINCE.
399  True if mmap clears memory so calloc doesn't need to. This is true
400  for standard unix mmap using /dev/zero and on WIN32 except for WINCE.
401 
402 USE_BUILTIN_FFS default: 0 (i.e., not used)
403  Causes malloc to use the builtin ffs() function to compute indices.
404  Some compilers may recognize and intrinsify ffs to be faster than the
405  supplied C version. Also, the case of x86 using gcc is special-cased
406  to an asm instruction, so is already as fast as it can be, and so
407  this setting has no effect. Similarly for Win32 under recent MS compilers.
408  (On most x86s, the asm version is only slightly faster than the C version.)
409 
410 malloc_getpagesize default: derive from system includes, or 4096.
411  The system page size. To the extent possible, this malloc manages
412  memory from the system in page-size units. This may be (and
413  usually is) a function rather than a constant. This is ignored
414  if WIN32, where page size is determined using getSystemInfo during
415  initialization.
416 
417 USE_DEV_RANDOM default: 0 (i.e., not used)
418  Causes malloc to use /dev/random to initialize secure magic seed for
419  stamping footers. Otherwise, the current time is used.
420 
421 NO_MALLINFO default: 0
422  If defined, don't compile "mallinfo". This can be a simple way
423  of dealing with mismatches between system declarations and
424  those in this file.
425 
426 MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE default: size_t
427  The type of the fields in the mallinfo struct. This was originally
428  defined as "int" in SVID etc, but is more usefully defined as
429  size_t. The value is used only if HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H is not set
430 
431 NO_MALLOC_STATS default: 0
432  If defined, don't compile "malloc_stats". This avoids calls to
433  fprintf and bringing in stdio dependencies you might not want.
434 
435 REALLOC_ZERO_BYTES_FREES default: not defined
436  This should be set if a call to realloc with zero bytes should
437  be the same as a call to free. Some people think it should. Otherwise,
438  since this malloc returns a unique pointer for malloc(0), so does
439  realloc(p, 0).
440 
441 LACKS_UNISTD_H, LACKS_FCNTL_H, LACKS_SYS_PARAM_H, LACKS_SYS_MMAN_H
442 LACKS_STRINGS_H, LACKS_STRING_H, LACKS_SYS_TYPES_H, LACKS_ERRNO_H
443 LACKS_STDLIB_H LACKS_SCHED_H LACKS_TIME_H default: NOT defined unless on WIN32
444  Define these if your system does not have these header files.
445  You might need to manually insert some of the declarations they provide.
446 
447 DEFAULT_GRANULARITY default: page size if MORECORE_CONTIGUOUS,
448  system_info.dwAllocationGranularity in WIN32,
449  otherwise 64K.
450  Also settable using mallopt(M_GRANULARITY, x)
451  The unit for allocating and deallocating memory from the system. On
452  most systems with contiguous MORECORE, there is no reason to
453  make this more than a page. However, systems with MMAP tend to
454  either require or encourage larger granularities. You can increase
455  this value to prevent system allocation functions to be called so
456  often, especially if they are slow. The value must be at least one
457  page and must be a power of two. Setting to 0 causes initialization
458  to either page size or win32 region size. (Note: In previous
459  versions of malloc, the equivalent of this option was called
460  "TOP_PAD")
461 
462 DEFAULT_TRIM_THRESHOLD default: 2MB
463  Also settable using mallopt(M_TRIM_THRESHOLD, x)
464  The maximum amount of unused top-most memory to keep before
465  releasing via malloc_trim in free(). Automatic trimming is mainly
466  useful in long-lived programs using contiguous MORECORE. Because
467  trimming via sbrk can be slow on some systems, and can sometimes be
468  wasteful (in cases where programs immediately afterward allocate
469  more large chunks) the value should be high enough so that your
470  overall system performance would improve by releasing this much
471  memory. As a rough guide, you might set to a value close to the
472  average size of a process (program) running on your system.
473  Releasing this much memory would allow such a process to run in
474  memory. Generally, it is worth tuning trim thresholds when a
475  program undergoes phases where several large chunks are allocated
476  and released in ways that can reuse each other's storage, perhaps
477  mixed with phases where there are no such chunks at all. The trim
478  value must be greater than page size to have any useful effect. To
479  disable trimming completely, you can set to MAX_SIZE_T. Note that the trick
480  some people use of mallocing a huge space and then freeing it at
481  program startup, in an attempt to reserve system memory, doesn't
482  have the intended effect under automatic trimming, since that memory
483  will immediately be returned to the system.
484 
485 DEFAULT_MMAP_THRESHOLD default: 256K
486  Also settable using mallopt(M_MMAP_THRESHOLD, x)
487  The request size threshold for using MMAP to directly service a
488  request. Requests of at least this size that cannot be allocated
489  using already-existing space will be serviced via mmap. (If enough
490  normal freed space already exists it is used instead.) Using mmap
491  segregates relatively large chunks of memory so that they can be
492  individually obtained and released from the host system. A request
493  serviced through mmap is never reused by any other request (at least
494  not directly; the system may just so happen to remap successive
495  requests to the same locations). Segregating space in this way has
496  the benefits that: Mmapped space can always be individually released
497  back to the system, which helps keep the system level memory demands
498  of a long-lived program low. Also, mapped memory doesn't become
499  `locked' between other chunks, as can happen with normally allocated
500  chunks, which means that even trimming via malloc_trim would not
501  release them. However, it has the disadvantage that the space
502  cannot be reclaimed, consolidated, and then used to service later
503  requests, as happens with normal chunks. The advantages of mmap
504  nearly always outweigh disadvantages for "large" chunks, but the
505  value of "large" may vary across systems. The default is an
506  empirically derived value that works well in most systems. You can
507  disable mmap by setting to MAX_SIZE_T.
508 
509 MAX_RELEASE_CHECK_RATE default: 4095 unless not HAVE_MMAP
510  The number of consolidated frees between checks to release
511  unused segments when freeing. When using non-contiguous segments,
512  especially with multiple mspaces, checking only for topmost space
513  doesn't always suffice to trigger trimming. To compensate for this,
514  free() will, with a period of MAX_RELEASE_CHECK_RATE (or the
515  current number of segments, if greater) try to release unused
516  segments to the OS when freeing chunks that result in
517  consolidation. The best value for this parameter is a compromise
518  between slowing down frees with relatively costly checks that
519  rarely trigger versus holding on to unused memory. To effectively
520  disable, set to MAX_SIZE_T. This may lead to a very slight speed
521  improvement at the expense of carrying around more memory.
522 */
523

527 #endif /* DLMALLOC_VERSION */

531 #endif

734 #if !NO_MALLINFO
735 /*
736  This version of malloc supports the standard SVID/XPG mallinfo
737  routine that returns a struct containing usage properties and
738  statistics. It should work on any system that has a
739  /usr/include/malloc.h defining struct mallinfo. The main
740  declaration needed is the mallinfo struct that is returned (by-copy)
741  by mallinfo(). The malloinfo struct contains a bunch of fields that
742  are not even meaningful in this version of malloc. These fields are
743  are instead filled by mallinfo() with other numbers that might be of
744  interest.
745 
746  HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H should be set if you have a
747  /usr/include/malloc.h file that includes a declaration of struct
748  mallinfo. If so, it is included; else a compliant version is
749  declared below. These must be precisely the same for mallinfo() to
750  work. The original SVID version of this struct, defined on most
751  systems with mallinfo, declares all fields as ints. But some others
752  define as unsigned long. If your system defines the fields using a
753  type of different width than listed here, you MUST #include your
754  system version and #define HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H.
755 */
756 
757 /* #define HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H */
758 
759 #ifdef HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H
760 #include "/usr/include/malloc.h"
761 #else /* HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H */
762 #ifndef STRUCT_MALLINFO_DECLARED
763 /* HP-UX (and others?) redefines mallinfo unless _STRUCT_MALLINFO is defined */
764 #define _STRUCT_MALLINFO
765 #define STRUCT_MALLINFO_DECLARED 1
766 struct mallinfo {
767  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE arena; /* non-mmapped space allocated from system */
768  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE ordblks; /* number of free chunks */
769  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE smblks; /* always 0 */
770  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE hblks; /* always 0 */
771  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE hblkhd; /* space in mmapped regions */
772  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE usmblks; /* maximum total allocated space */
773  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE fsmblks; /* always 0 */
774  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE uordblks; /* total allocated space */
775  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE fordblks; /* total free space */
776  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE keepcost; /* releasable (via malloc_trim) space */
777 };
778 #endif /* STRUCT_MALLINFO_DECLARED */
779 #endif /* HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H */
780 #endif /* NO_MALLINFO */

843 /*
844  malloc(size_t n)
845  Returns a pointer to a newly allocated chunk of at least n bytes, or
846  null if no space is available, in which case errno is set to ENOMEM
847  on ANSI C systems.
848 
849  If n is zero, malloc returns a minimum-sized chunk. (The minimum
850  size is 16 bytes on most 32bit systems, and 32 bytes on 64bit
851  systems.) Note that size_t is an unsigned type, so calls with
852  arguments that would be negative if signed are interpreted as
853  requests for huge amounts of space, which will often fail. The
854  maximum supported value of n differs across systems, but is in all
855  cases less than the maximum representable value of a size_t.
856 */
857 DLMALLOC_EXPORT void* dlmalloc(size_t);
858 
859 /*
860  free(void* p)
861  Releases the chunk of memory pointed to by p, that had been previously
862  allocated using malloc or a related routine such as realloc.
863  It has no effect if p is null. If p was not malloced or already
864  freed, free(p) will by default cause the current program to abort.
865 */
866 DLMALLOC_EXPORT void dlfree(void*);
867 
868 /*
869  calloc(size_t n_elements, size_t element_size);
870  Returns a pointer to n_elements * element_size bytes, with all locations
871  set to zero.
872 */
873 DLMALLOC_EXPORT void* dlcalloc(size_t, size_t);
874 
875 /*
876  realloc(void* p, size_t n)
877  Returns a pointer to a chunk of size n that contains the same data
878  as does chunk p up to the minimum of (n, p's size) bytes, or null
879  if no space is available.
880 
881  The returned pointer may or may not be the same as p. The algorithm
882  prefers extending p in most cases when possible, otherwise it
883  employs the equivalent of a malloc-copy-free sequence.
884 
885  If p is null, realloc is equivalent to malloc.
886 
887  If space is not available, realloc returns null, errno is set (if on
888  ANSI) and p is NOT freed.
889 
890  if n is for fewer bytes than already held by p, the newly unused
891  space is lopped off and freed if possible. realloc with a size
892  argument of zero (re)allocates a minimum-sized chunk.
893 
894  The old unix realloc convention of allowing the last-free'd chunk
895  to be used as an argument to realloc is not supported.
896 */
897 DLMALLOC_EXPORT void* dlrealloc(void*, size_t);
898 
899 /*
900  realloc_in_place(void* p, size_t n)
901  Resizes the space allocated for p to size n, only if this can be
902  done without moving p (i.e., only if there is adjacent space
903  available if n is greater than p's current allocated size, or n is
904  less than or equal to p's size). This may be used instead of plain
905  realloc if an alternative allocation strategy is needed upon failure
906  to expand space; for example, reallocation of a buffer that must be
907  memory-aligned or cleared. You can use realloc_in_place to trigger
908  these alternatives only when needed.
909 
910  Returns p if successful; otherwise null.
911 */
912 DLMALLOC_EXPORT void* dlrealloc_in_place(void*, size_t);
913 
914 /*
915  memalign(size_t alignment, size_t n);
916  Returns a pointer to a newly allocated chunk of n bytes, aligned
917  in accord with the alignment argument.
918 
919  The alignment argument should be a power of two. If the argument is
920  not a power of two, the nearest greater power is used.
921  8-byte alignment is guaranteed by normal malloc calls, so don't
922  bother calling memalign with an argument of 8 or less.
923 
924  Overreliance on memalign is a sure way to fragment space.
925 */
926 DLMALLOC_EXPORT void* dlmemalign(size_t, size_t);
927 
928 /*
929  int posix_memalign(void** pp, size_t alignment, size_t n);
930  Allocates a chunk of n bytes, aligned in accord with the alignment
931  argument. Differs from memalign only in that it (1) assigns the
932  allocated memory to *pp rather than returning it, (2) fails and
933  returns EINVAL if the alignment is not a power of two (3) fails and
934  returns ENOMEM if memory cannot be allocated.
935 */
936 DLMALLOC_EXPORT int dlposix_memalign(void**, size_t, size_t);
937 
938 /*
939  valloc(size_t n);
940  Equivalent to memalign(pagesize, n), where pagesize is the page
941  size of the system. If the pagesize is unknown, 4096 is used.
942 */
943 DLMALLOC_EXPORT void* dlvalloc(size_t);
944 
945 /*
946  mallopt(int parameter_number, int parameter_value)
947  Sets tunable parameters The format is to provide a
948  (parameter-number, parameter-value) pair. mallopt then sets the
949  corresponding parameter to the argument value if it can (i.e., so
950  long as the value is meaningful), and returns 1 if successful else
951  0. To workaround the fact that mallopt is specified to use int,
952  not size_t parameters, the value -1 is specially treated as the
953  maximum unsigned size_t value.
954 
955  SVID/XPG/ANSI defines four standard param numbers for mallopt,
956  normally defined in malloc.h. None of these are use in this malloc,
957  so setting them has no effect. But this malloc also supports other
958  options in mallopt. See below for details. Briefly, supported
959  parameters are as follows (listed defaults are for "typical"
960  configurations).
961 
962  Symbol param # default allowed param values
963  M_TRIM_THRESHOLD -1 2*1024*1024 any (-1 disables)
964  M_GRANULARITY -2 page size any power of 2 >= page size
965  M_MMAP_THRESHOLD -3 256*1024 any (or 0 if no MMAP support)
966 */
967 DLMALLOC_EXPORT int dlmallopt(int, int);
968 
969 /*
970  malloc_footprint();
971  Returns the number of bytes obtained from the system. The total
972  number of bytes allocated by malloc, realloc etc., is less than this
973  value. Unlike mallinfo, this function returns only a precomputed
974  result, so can be called frequently to monitor memory consumption.
975  Even if locks are otherwise defined, this function does not use them,
976  so results might not be up to date.
977 */
978 DLMALLOC_EXPORT size_t dlmalloc_footprint(void);
979 
980 /*
981  malloc_max_footprint();
982  Returns the maximum number of bytes obtained from the system. This
983  value will be greater than current footprint if deallocated space
984  has been reclaimed by the system. The peak number of bytes allocated
985  by malloc, realloc etc., is less than this value. Unlike mallinfo,
986  this function returns only a precomputed result, so can be called
987  frequently to monitor memory consumption. Even if locks are
988  otherwise defined, this function does not use them, so results might
989  not be up to date.
990 */
991 DLMALLOC_EXPORT size_t dlmalloc_max_footprint(void);
992 
993 /*
994  malloc_footprint_limit();
995  Returns the number of bytes that the heap is allowed to obtain from
996  the system, returning the last value returned by
997  malloc_set_footprint_limit, or the maximum size_t value if
998  never set. The returned value reflects a permission. There is no
999  guarantee that this number of bytes can actually be obtained from
1000  the system.
1001 */
1002 DLMALLOC_EXPORT size_t dlmalloc_footprint_limit();
1003 
1004 /*
1005  malloc_set_footprint_limit();
1006  Sets the maximum number of bytes to obtain from the system, causing
1007  failure returns from malloc and related functions upon attempts to
1008  exceed this value. The argument value may be subject to page
1009  rounding to an enforceable limit; this actual value is returned.
1010  Using an argument of the maximum possible size_t effectively
1011  disables checks. If the argument is less than or equal to the
1012  current malloc_footprint, then all future allocations that require
1013  additional system memory will fail. However, invocation cannot
1014  retroactively deallocate existing used memory.
1015 */
1016 DLMALLOC_EXPORT size_t dlmalloc_set_footprint_limit(size_t bytes);
1017 
1018 #if MALLOC_INSPECT_ALL
1019 /*
1020  malloc_inspect_all(void(*handler)(void *start,
1021  void *end,
1022  size_t used_bytes,
1023  void* callback_arg),
1024  void* arg);
1025  Traverses the heap and calls the given handler for each managed
1026  region, skipping all bytes that are (or may be) used for bookkeeping
1027  purposes. Traversal does not include include chunks that have been
1028  directly memory mapped. Each reported region begins at the start
1029  address, and continues up to but not including the end address. The
1030  first used_bytes of the region contain allocated data. If
1031  used_bytes is zero, the region is unallocated. The handler is
1032  invoked with the given callback argument. If locks are defined, they
1033  are held during the entire traversal. It is a bad idea to invoke
1034  other malloc functions from within the handler.
1035 
1036  For example, to count the number of in-use chunks with size greater
1037  than 1000, you could write:
1038  static int count = 0;
1039  void count_chunks(void* start, void* end, size_t used, void* arg) {
1040  if (used >= 1000) ++count;
1041  }
1042  then:
1043  malloc_inspect_all(count_chunks, NULL);
1044 
1045  malloc_inspect_all is compiled only if MALLOC_INSPECT_ALL is defined.
1046 */
1047 DLMALLOC_EXPORT void dlmalloc_inspect_all(void(*handler)(void*, void *, size_t, void*),
1048  void* arg);
1049 
1050 #endif /* MALLOC_INSPECT_ALL */
1051 
1052 #if !NO_MALLINFO
1053 /*
1054  mallinfo()
1055  Returns (by copy) a struct containing various summary statistics:
1056 
1057  arena: current total non-mmapped bytes allocated from system
1058  ordblks: the number of free chunks
1059  smblks: always zero.
1060  hblks: current number of mmapped regions
1061  hblkhd: total bytes held in mmapped regions
1062  usmblks: the maximum total allocated space. This will be greater
1063  than current total if trimming has occurred.
1064  fsmblks: always zero
1065  uordblks: current total allocated space (normal or mmapped)
1066  fordblks: total free space
1067  keepcost: the maximum number of bytes that could ideally be released
1068  back to system via malloc_trim. ("ideally" means that
1069  it ignores page restrictions etc.)
1070 
1071  Because these fields are ints, but internal bookkeeping may
1072  be kept as longs, the reported values may wrap around zero and
1073  thus be inaccurate.
1074 */
1075 DLMALLOC_EXPORT struct mallinfo dlmallinfo(void);
1076 #endif /* NO_MALLINFO */
1077 
1078 /*
1079  independent_calloc(size_t n_elements, size_t element_size, void* chunks[]);
1080 
1081  independent_calloc is similar to calloc, but instead of returning a
1082  single cleared space, it returns an array of pointers to n_elements
1083  independent elements that can hold contents of size elem_size, each
1084  of which starts out cleared, and can be independently freed,
1085  realloc'ed etc. The elements are guaranteed to be adjacently
1086  allocated (this is not guaranteed to occur with multiple callocs or
1087  mallocs), which may also improve cache locality in some
1088  applications.
1089 
1090  The "chunks" argument is optional (i.e., may be null, which is
1091  probably the most typical usage). If it is null, the returned array
1092  is itself dynamically allocated and should also be freed when it is
1093  no longer needed. Otherwise, the chunks array must be of at least
1094  n_elements in length. It is filled in with the pointers to the
1095  chunks.
1096 
1097  In either case, independent_calloc returns this pointer array, or
1098  null if the allocation failed. If n_elements is zero and "chunks"
1099  is null, it returns a chunk representing an array with zero elements
1100  (which should be freed if not wanted).
1101 
1102  Each element must be freed when it is no longer needed. This can be
1103  done all at once using bulk_free.
1104 
1105  independent_calloc simplifies and speeds up implementations of many
1106  kinds of pools. It may also be useful when constructing large data
1107  structures that initially have a fixed number of fixed-sized nodes,
1108  but the number is not known at compile time, and some of the nodes
1109  may later need to be freed. For example:
1110 
1111  struct Node { int item; struct Node* next; };
1112 
1113  struct Node* build_list() {
1114  struct Node** pool;
1115  int n = read_number_of_nodes_needed();
1116  if (n <= 0) return 0;
1117  pool = (struct Node**)(independent_calloc(n, sizeof(struct Node), 0);
1118  if (pool == 0) die();
1119  // organize into a linked list...
1120  struct Node* first = pool[0];
1121  for (i = 0; i < n-1; ++i)
1122  pool[i]->next = pool[i+1];
1123  free(pool); // Can now free the array (or not, if it is needed later)
1124  return first;
1125  }
1126 */
1127 DLMALLOC_EXPORT void** dlindependent_calloc(size_t, size_t, void**);
1128 
1129 /*
1130  independent_comalloc(size_t n_elements, size_t sizes[], void* chunks[]);
1131 
1132  independent_comalloc allocates, all at once, a set of n_elements
1133  chunks with sizes indicated in the "sizes" array. It returns
1134  an array of pointers to these elements, each of which can be
1135  independently freed, realloc'ed etc. The elements are guaranteed to
1136  be adjacently allocated (this is not guaranteed to occur with
1137  multiple callocs or mallocs), which may also improve cache locality
1138  in some applications.
1139 
1140  The "chunks" argument is optional (i.e., may be null). If it is null
1141  the returned array is itself dynamically allocated and should also
1142  be freed when it is no longer needed. Otherwise, the chunks array
1143  must be of at least n_elements in length. It is filled in with the
1144  pointers to the chunks.
1145 
1146  In either case, independent_comalloc returns this pointer array, or
1147  null if the allocation failed. If n_elements is zero and chunks is
1148  null, it returns a chunk representing an array with zero elements
1149  (which should be freed if not wanted).
1150 
1151  Each element must be freed when it is no longer needed. This can be
1152  done all at once using bulk_free.
1153 
1154  independent_comallac differs from independent_calloc in that each
1155  element may have a different size, and also that it does not
1156  automatically clear elements.
1157 
1158  independent_comalloc can be used to speed up allocation in cases
1159  where several structs or objects must always be allocated at the
1160  same time. For example:
1161 
1162  struct Head { ... }
1163  struct Foot { ... }
1164 
1165  void send_message(char* msg) {
1166  int msglen = strlen(msg);
1167  size_t sizes[3] = { sizeof(struct Head), msglen, sizeof(struct Foot) };
1168  void* chunks[3];
1169  if (independent_comalloc(3, sizes, chunks) == 0)
1170  die();
1171  struct Head* head = (struct Head*)(chunks[0]);
1172  char* body = (char*)(chunks[1]);
1173  struct Foot* foot = (struct Foot*)(chunks[2]);
1174  // ...
1175  }
1176 
1177  In general though, independent_comalloc is worth using only for
1178  larger values of n_elements. For small values, you probably won't
1179  detect enough difference from series of malloc calls to bother.
1180 
1181  Overuse of independent_comalloc can increase overall memory usage,
1182  since it cannot reuse existing noncontiguous small chunks that
1183  might be available for some of the elements.
1184 */
1185 DLMALLOC_EXPORT void** dlindependent_comalloc(size_t, size_t*, void**);
1186 
1187 /*
1188  bulk_free(void* array[], size_t n_elements)
1189  Frees and clears (sets to null) each non-null pointer in the given
1190  array. This is likely to be faster than freeing them one-by-one.
1191  If footers are used, pointers that have been allocated in different
1192  mspaces are not freed or cleared, and the count of all such pointers
1193  is returned. For large arrays of pointers with poor locality, it
1194  may be worthwhile to sort this array before calling bulk_free.
1195 */
1196 DLMALLOC_EXPORT size_t dlbulk_free(void**, size_t n_elements);
1197 
1198 /*
1199  pvalloc(size_t n);
1200  Equivalent to valloc(minimum-page-that-holds(n)), that is,
1201  round up n to nearest pagesize.
1202  */
1203 DLMALLOC_EXPORT void* dlpvalloc(size_t);
1204 
1205 /*
1206  malloc_trim(size_t pad);
1207 
1208  If possible, gives memory back to the system (via negative arguments
1209  to sbrk) if there is unused memory at the `high' end of the malloc
1210  pool or in unused MMAP segments. You can call this after freeing
1211  large blocks of memory to potentially reduce the system-level memory
1212  requirements of a program. However, it cannot guarantee to reduce
1213  memory. Under some allocation patterns, some large free blocks of
1214  memory will be locked between two used chunks, so they cannot be
1215  given back to the system.
1216 
1217  The `pad' argument to malloc_trim represents the amount of free
1218  trailing space to leave untrimmed. If this argument is zero, only
1219  the minimum amount of memory to maintain internal data structures
1220  will be left. Non-zero arguments can be supplied to maintain enough
1221  trailing space to service future expected allocations without having
1222  to re-obtain memory from the system.
1223 
1224  Malloc_trim returns 1 if it actually released any memory, else 0.
1225 */
1226 DLMALLOC_EXPORT int dlmalloc_trim(size_t);
1227 
1228 /*
1229  malloc_stats();
1230  Prints on stderr the amount of space obtained from the system (both
1231  via sbrk and mmap), the maximum amount (which may be more than
1232  current if malloc_trim and/or munmap got called), and the current
1233  number of bytes allocated via malloc (or realloc, etc) but not yet
1234  freed. Note that this is the number of bytes allocated, not the
1235  number requested. It will be larger than the number requested
1236  because of alignment and bookkeeping overhead. Because it includes
1237  alignment wastage as being in use, this figure may be greater than
1238  zero even when no user-level chunks are allocated.
1239 
1240  The reported current and maximum system memory can be inaccurate if
1241  a program makes other calls to system memory allocation functions
1242  (normally sbrk) outside of malloc.
1243 
1244  malloc_stats prints only the most commonly interesting statistics.
1245  More information can be obtained by calling mallinfo.
1246 */
1247 DLMALLOC_EXPORT void dlmalloc_stats(void);
1248 
1249 /*
1250  malloc_usable_size(void* p);
1251 
1252  Returns the number of bytes you can actually use in
1253  an allocated chunk, which may be more than you requested (although
1254  often not) due to alignment and minimum size constraints.
1255  You can use this many bytes without worrying about
1256  overwriting other allocated objects. This is not a particularly great
1257  programming practice. malloc_usable_size can be more useful in
1258  debugging and assertions, for example:
1259 
1260  p = malloc(n);
1261  assert(malloc_usable_size(p) >= 256);
1262 */
1263 size_t dlmalloc_usable_size(void*);
1264 
1265 #endif /* ONLY_MSPACES */
1266

1270  mspace is an opaque type representing an independent
1271  region of space that supports mspace_malloc, etc.
1272 */
1273 typedef void* mspace;
1274 
1275 /*
1276  create_mspace creates and returns a new independent space with the
1277  given initial capacity, or, if 0, the default granularity size. It
1278  returns null if there is no system memory available to create the
1279  space. If argument locked is non-zero, the space uses a separate
1280  lock to control access. The capacity of the space will grow
1281  dynamically as needed to service mspace_malloc requests. You can
1282  control the sizes of incremental increases of this space by
1283  compiling with a different DEFAULT_GRANULARITY or dynamically
1284  setting with mallopt(M_GRANULARITY, value).
1285 */
1286 DLMALLOC_EXPORT mspace create_mspace(size_t capacity, int locked);
1287 
1288 /*

1290  of its memory back to the system, returning the total number of
1291  bytes freed. After destruction, the results of access to all memory
1292  used by the space become undefined.
1293 */
1294 DLMALLOC_EXPORT size_t destroy_mspace(mspace msp);

1298  of a new mspace. Part (less than 128*sizeof(size_t) bytes) of this
1299  space is used for bookkeeping, so the capacity must be at least this
1300  large. (Otherwise 0 is returned.) When this initial space is
1301  exhausted, additional memory will be obtained from the system.
1302  Destroying this space will deallocate all additionally allocated
1303  space (if possible) but not the initial base.

1305 DLMALLOC_EXPORT mspace create_mspace_with_base(void* base, size_t capacity, int locked);

1307 /*
1308  mspace_track_large_chunks controls whether requests for large chunks
1309  are allocated in their own untracked mmapped regions, separate from
1310  others in this mspace. By default large chunks are not tracked,
1311  which reduces fragmentation. However, such chunks are not
1312  necessarily released to the system upon destroy_mspace. Enabling
1313  tracking by setting to true may increase fragmentation, but avoids
1314  leakage when relying on destroy_mspace to release all memory
1315  allocated using this space. The function returns the previous
1316  setting.

1598 /* ------------------- size_t and alignment properties -------------------- */
1599 
1600 /* The byte and bit size of a size_t */
1601 #define SIZE_T_SIZE (sizeof(size_t))
1602 #define SIZE_T_BITSIZE (sizeof(size_t) << 3)
1603 
1604 /* Some constants coerced to size_t */
1605 /* Annoying but necessary to avoid errors on some platforms */
1606 #define SIZE_T_ZERO ((size_t)0)
1607 #define SIZE_T_ONE ((size_t)1)
1608 #define SIZE_T_TWO ((size_t)2)
1609 #define SIZE_T_FOUR ((size_t)4)
1610 #define TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES (SIZE_T_SIZE<<1)
1611 #define FOUR_SIZE_T_SIZES (SIZE_T_SIZE<<2)
1612 #define SIX_SIZE_T_SIZES (FOUR_SIZE_T_SIZES+TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES)
1613 #define HALF_MAX_SIZE_T (MAX_SIZE_T / 2U)
1614 
1615 /* The bit mask value corresponding to MALLOC_ALIGNMENT */
1616 #define CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK (MALLOC_ALIGNMENT - SIZE_T_ONE)
1617 
1618 /* True if address a has acceptable alignment */
1619 #define is_aligned(A) (((size_t)((A)) & (CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK)) == 0)
1620 
1621 /* the number of bytes to offset an address to align it */
1622 #define align_offset(A)\
1623  ((((size_t)(A) & CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK) == 0)? 0 :\
1624  ((MALLOC_ALIGNMENT - ((size_t)(A) & CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK)) & CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK))
1625 
1626 /* -------------------------- MMAP preliminaries ------------------------- */
1627 
1628 /*
1629  If HAVE_MORECORE or HAVE_MMAP are false, we just define calls and
1630  checks to fail so compiler optimizer can delete code rather than
1631  using so many "#if"s.
1632 */
1633 
1634 
1635 /* MORECORE and MMAP must return MFAIL on failure */
1636 #define MFAIL ((void*)(MAX_SIZE_T))
1637 #define CMFAIL ((char*)(MFAIL)) /* defined for convenience */
1638 
1639 #if HAVE_MMAP
1640 
1641 #ifndef WIN32
1642 #define MUNMAP_DEFAULT(a, s) munmap((a), (s))
1643 #define MMAP_PROT (PROT_READ|PROT_WRITE)
1644 #if !defined(MAP_ANONYMOUS) && defined(MAP_ANON)
1645 #define MAP_ANONYMOUS MAP_ANON
1646 #endif /* MAP_ANON */
1647 #ifdef MAP_ANONYMOUS
1648 #define MMAP_FLAGS (MAP_PRIVATE|MAP_ANONYMOUS)
1649 #define MMAP_DEFAULT(s) mmap(0, (s), MMAP_PROT, MMAP_FLAGS, -1, 0)
1650 #else /* MAP_ANONYMOUS */
1651 /*
1652  Nearly all versions of mmap support MAP_ANONYMOUS, so the following
1653  is unlikely to be needed, but is supplied just in case.
1654 */
1655 #define MMAP_FLAGS (MAP_PRIVATE)
1656 static int dev_zero_fd = -1; /* Cached file descriptor for /dev/zero. */
1657 #define MMAP_DEFAULT(s) ((dev_zero_fd < 0) ? \
1658  (dev_zero_fd = open("/dev/zero", O_RDWR), \
1659  mmap(0, (s), MMAP_PROT, MMAP_FLAGS, dev_zero_fd, 0)) : \
1660  mmap(0, (s), MMAP_PROT, MMAP_FLAGS, dev_zero_fd, 0))
1661 #endif /* MAP_ANONYMOUS */
1662 
1663 #define DIRECT_MMAP_DEFAULT(s) MMAP_DEFAULT(s)
1664 
1665 #else /* WIN32 */
1666 
1667 /* Win32 MMAP via VirtualAlloc */
1668 static FORCEINLINE void* win32mmap(size_t size) {
1669  void* ptr = VirtualAlloc(0, size, MEM_RESERVE|MEM_COMMIT, PAGE_READWRITE);
1670  return (ptr != 0)? ptr: MFAIL;
1671 }
1672 
1673 /* For direct MMAP, use MEM_TOP_DOWN to minimize interference */
1674 static FORCEINLINE void* win32direct_mmap(size_t size) {
1675  void* ptr = VirtualAlloc(0, size, MEM_RESERVE|MEM_COMMIT|MEM_TOP_DOWN,
1676  PAGE_READWRITE);
1677  return (ptr != 0)? ptr: MFAIL;
1678 }
1679 
1680 /* This function supports releasing coalesed segments */
1681 static FORCEINLINE int win32munmap(void* ptr, size_t size) {
1682  MEMORY_BASIC_INFORMATION minfo;
1683  char* cptr = (char*)ptr;
1684  while (size) {
1685  if (VirtualQuery(cptr, &minfo, sizeof(minfo)) == 0)
1686  return -1;
1687  if (minfo.BaseAddress != cptr || minfo.AllocationBase != cptr ||
1688  minfo.State != MEM_COMMIT || minfo.RegionSize > size)
1689  return -1;
1690  if (VirtualFree(cptr, 0, MEM_RELEASE) == 0)
1691  return -1;
1692  cptr += minfo.RegionSize;
1693  size -= minfo.RegionSize;
1694  }
1695  return 0;
1696 }
1697 
1698 #define MMAP_DEFAULT(s) win32mmap(s)
1699 #define MUNMAP_DEFAULT(a, s) win32munmap((a), (s))
1700 #define DIRECT_MMAP_DEFAULT(s) win32direct_mmap(s)
1701 #endif /* WIN32 */

1774 
1775 /* --------------------------- Lock preliminaries ------------------------ */
1776 
1777 /*
1778  When locks are defined, there is one global lock, plus
1779  one per-mspace lock.
1780 
1781  The global lock_ensures that mparams.magic and other unique
1782  mparams values are initialized only once. It also protects
1783  sequences of calls to MORECORE. In many cases sys_alloc requires
1784  two calls, that should not be interleaved with calls by other
1785  threads. This does not protect against direct calls to MORECORE
1786  by other threads not using this lock, so there is still code to
1787  cope the best we can on interference.
1788 
1789  Per-mspace locks surround calls to malloc, free, etc.
1790  By default, locks are simple non-reentrant mutexes.
1791 
1792  Because lock-protected regions generally have bounded times, it is
1793  OK to use the supplied simple spinlocks. Spinlocks are likely to
1794  improve performance for lightly contended applications, but worsen
1795  performance under heavy contention.
1796 
1797  If USE_LOCKS is > 1, the definitions of lock routines here are
1798  bypassed, in which case you will need to define the type MLOCK_T,
1799  and at least INITIAL_LOCK, DESTROY_LOCK, ACQUIRE_LOCK, RELEASE_LOCK
1800  and TRY_LOCK. You must also declare a
1801  static MLOCK_T malloc_global_mutex = { initialization values };.
1802 
1803 */
1804 
1805 #if !USE_LOCKS
1806 #define USE_LOCK_BIT (0U)
1807 #define INITIAL_LOCK(l) (0)
1808 #define DESTROY_LOCK(l) (0)
1809 #define ACQUIRE_MALLOC_GLOBAL_LOCK()
1810 #define RELEASE_MALLOC_GLOBAL_LOCK()
1811 
1812 #else
1813 #if USE_LOCKS > 1
1814 /* ----------------------- User-defined locks ------------------------ */
1815 /* Define your own lock implementation here */
1816 /* #define INITIAL_LOCK(lk) ... */
1817 /* #define DESTROY_LOCK(lk) ... */
1818 /* #define ACQUIRE_LOCK(lk) ... */
1819 /* #define RELEASE_LOCK(lk) ... */
1820 /* #define TRY_LOCK(lk) ... */
1821 /* static MLOCK_T malloc_global_mutex = ... */
1822 
1823 #elif USE_SPIN_LOCKS
1824 
1825 /* First, define CAS_LOCK and CLEAR_LOCK on ints */
1826 /* Note CAS_LOCK defined to return 0 on success */
1827 
1828 #if defined(__GNUC__)&& (__GNUC__ > 4 || (__GNUC__ == 4 && __GNUC_MINOR__ >= 1))
1829 #define CAS_LOCK(sl) __sync_lock_test_and_set(sl, 1)
1830 #define CLEAR_LOCK(sl) __sync_lock_release(sl)
1831 
1832 #elif (defined(__GNUC__) && (defined(__i386__) || defined(__x86_64__)))
1833 /* Custom spin locks for older gcc on x86 */
1834 static FORCEINLINE int x86_cas_lock(int *sl) {
1835  int ret;
1836  int val = 1;
1837  int cmp = 0;
1838  __asm__ __volatile__ ("lock; cmpxchgl %1, %2"
1839  : "=a" (ret)
1840  : "r" (val), "m" (*(sl)), "0"(cmp)
1841  : "memory", "cc");
1842  return ret;
1843 }
1844 
1845 static FORCEINLINE void x86_clear_lock(int* sl) {
1846  assert(*sl != 0);
1847  int prev = 0;
1848  int ret;
1849  __asm__ __volatile__ ("lock; xchgl %0, %1"
1850  : "=r" (ret)
1851  : "m" (*(sl)), "0"(prev)
1852  : "memory");
1853 }
1854 
1855 #define CAS_LOCK(sl) x86_cas_lock(sl)
1856 #define CLEAR_LOCK(sl) x86_clear_lock(sl)
1857 
1858 #else /* Win32 MSC */
1859 #define CAS_LOCK(sl) interlockedexchange(sl, (LONG)1)
1860 #define CLEAR_LOCK(sl) interlockedexchange (sl, (LONG)0)
1861 
1862 #endif /* ... gcc spins locks ... */
1863 
1864 /* How to yield for a spin lock */
1865 #define SPINS_PER_YIELD 63
1866 #if defined(_MSC_VER)
1867 #define SLEEP_EX_DURATION 50 /* delay for yield/sleep */
1868 #define SPIN_LOCK_YIELD SleepEx(SLEEP_EX_DURATION, FALSE)
1869 #elif defined (__SVR4) && defined (__sun) /* solaris */
1870 #define SPIN_LOCK_YIELD thr_yield();
1871 #elif !defined(LACKS_SCHED_H)
1872 #define SPIN_LOCK_YIELD sched_yield();
1873 #else
1874 #define SPIN_LOCK_YIELD
1875 #endif /* ... yield ... */
1876 
1877 #if !defined(USE_RECURSIVE_LOCKS) || USE_RECURSIVE_LOCKS == 0
1878 /* Plain spin locks use single word (embedded in malloc_states) */
1879 static int spin_acquire_lock(int *sl) {
1880  int spins = 0;
1881  while (*(volatile int *)sl != 0 || CAS_LOCK(sl)) {
1882  if ((++spins & SPINS_PER_YIELD) == 0) {
1883  SPIN_LOCK_YIELD;
1884  }
1885  }
1886  return 0;
1887 }
1888 
1889 #define MLOCK_T int
1890 #define TRY_LOCK(sl) !CAS_LOCK(sl)
1891 #define RELEASE_LOCK(sl) CLEAR_LOCK(sl)
1892 #define ACQUIRE_LOCK(sl) (CAS_LOCK(sl)? spin_acquire_lock(sl) : 0)
1893 #define INITIAL_LOCK(sl) (*sl = 0)
1894 #define DESTROY_LOCK(sl) (0)
1895 static MLOCK_T malloc_global_mutex = 0;
1896 
1897 #else /* USE_RECURSIVE_LOCKS */
1898 /* types for lock owners */
1899 #ifdef WIN32
1900 #define THREAD_ID_T DWORD
1901 #define CURRENT_THREAD GetCurrentThreadId()
1902 #define EQ_OWNER(X,Y) ((X) == (Y))
1903 #else
1904 /*
1905  Note: the following assume that pthread_t is a type that can be
1906  initialized to (casted) zero. If this is not the case, you will need to
1907  somehow redefine these or not use spin locks.
1908 */
1909 #define THREAD_ID_T pthread_t
1910 #define CURRENT_THREAD pthread_self()
1911 #define EQ_OWNER(X,Y) pthread_equal(X, Y)
1912 #endif
1913 
1914 struct malloc_recursive_lock {
1915  int sl;
1916  unsigned int c;
1917  THREAD_ID_T threadid;
1918 };
1919 
1920 #define MLOCK_T struct malloc_recursive_lock
1921 static MLOCK_T malloc_global_mutex = { 0, 0, (THREAD_ID_T)0};
1922 
1923 static FORCEINLINE void recursive_release_lock(MLOCK_T *lk) {
1924  assert(lk->sl != 0);
1925  if (--lk->c == 0) {
1926  CLEAR_LOCK(&lk->sl);
1927  }
1928 }
1929 
1930 static FORCEINLINE int recursive_acquire_lock(MLOCK_T *lk) {
1931  THREAD_ID_T mythreadid = CURRENT_THREAD;
1932  int spins = 0;
1933  for (;;) {
1934  if (*((volatile int *)(&lk->sl)) == 0) {
1935  if (!CAS_LOCK(&lk->sl)) {
1936  lk->threadid = mythreadid;
1937  lk->c = 1;
1938  return 0;
1939  }
1940  }
1941  else if (EQ_OWNER(lk->threadid, mythreadid)) {
1942  ++lk->c;
1943  return 0;
1944  }
1945  if ((++spins & SPINS_PER_YIELD) == 0) {
1946  SPIN_LOCK_YIELD;
1947  }
1948  }
1949 }
1950 
1951 static FORCEINLINE int recursive_try_lock(MLOCK_T *lk) {
1952  THREAD_ID_T mythreadid = CURRENT_THREAD;
1953  if (*((volatile int *)(&lk->sl)) == 0) {
1954  if (!CAS_LOCK(&lk->sl)) {
1955  lk->threadid = mythreadid;
1956  lk->c = 1;
1957  return 1;
1958  }
1959  }
1960  else if (EQ_OWNER(lk->threadid, mythreadid)) {
1961  ++lk->c;
1962  return 1;
1963  }
1964  return 0;
1965 }
1966 
1967 #define RELEASE_LOCK(lk) recursive_release_lock(lk)
1968 #define TRY_LOCK(lk) recursive_try_lock(lk)
1969 #define ACQUIRE_LOCK(lk) recursive_acquire_lock(lk)
1970 #define INITIAL_LOCK(lk) ((lk)->threadid = (THREAD_ID_T)0, (lk)->sl = 0, (lk)->c = 0)
1971 #define DESTROY_LOCK(lk) (0)
1972 #endif /* USE_RECURSIVE_LOCKS */
1973 
1974 #elif defined(WIN32) /* Win32 critical sections */
1975 #define MLOCK_T CRITICAL_SECTION
1976 #define ACQUIRE_LOCK(lk) (EnterCriticalSection(lk), 0)
1977 #define RELEASE_LOCK(lk) LeaveCriticalSection(lk)
1978 #define TRY_LOCK(lk) TryEnterCriticalSection(lk)
1979 #define INITIAL_LOCK(lk) (!InitializeCriticalSectionAndSpinCount((lk), 0x80000000|4000))
1980 #define DESTROY_LOCK(lk) (DeleteCriticalSection(lk), 0)
1981 #define NEED_GLOBAL_LOCK_INIT
1982 
1983 static MLOCK_T malloc_global_mutex;
1984 static volatile LONG malloc_global_mutex_status;
1985 
1986 /* Use spin loop to initialize global lock */
1987 static void init_malloc_global_mutex() {
1988  for (;;) {
1989  long stat = malloc_global_mutex_status;
1990  if (stat > 0)
1991  return;
1992  /* transition to < 0 while initializing, then to > 0) */
1993  if (stat == 0 &&
1994  interlockedcompareexchange(&malloc_global_mutex_status, (LONG)-1, (LONG)0) == 0) {
1995  InitializeCriticalSection(&malloc_global_mutex);
1996  interlockedexchange(&malloc_global_mutex_status, (LONG)1);
1997  return;
1998  }
1999  SleepEx(0, FALSE);
2000  }
2001 }
2002 
2003 #else /* pthreads-based locks */
2004 #define MLOCK_T pthread_mutex_t
2005 #define ACQUIRE_LOCK(lk) pthread_mutex_lock(lk)
2006 #define RELEASE_LOCK(lk) pthread_mutex_unlock(lk)
2007 #define TRY_LOCK(lk) (!pthread_mutex_trylock(lk))
2008 #define INITIAL_LOCK(lk) pthread_init_lock(lk)
2009 #define DESTROY_LOCK(lk) pthread_mutex_destroy(lk)
2010 
2011 #if defined(USE_RECURSIVE_LOCKS) && USE_RECURSIVE_LOCKS != 0 && defined(linux) && !defined(PTHREAD_MUTEX_RECURSIVE)
2012 /* Cope with old-style linux recursive lock initialization by adding */
2013 /* skipped internal declaration from pthread.h */
2014 extern int pthread_mutexattr_setkind_np __P ((pthread_mutexattr_t *__attr,
2015  int __kind));
2016 #define PTHREAD_MUTEX_RECURSIVE PTHREAD_MUTEX_RECURSIVE_NP
2017 #define pthread_mutexattr_settype(x,y) pthread_mutexattr_setkind_np(x,y)
2018 #endif /* USE_RECURSIVE_LOCKS ... */
2019 
2020 static MLOCK_T malloc_global_mutex = PTHREAD_MUTEX_INITIALIZER;
2021 
2022 static int pthread_init_lock (MLOCK_T *lk) {
2023  pthread_mutexattr_t attr;
2024  if (pthread_mutexattr_init(&attr)) return 1;
2025 #if defined(USE_RECURSIVE_LOCKS) && USE_RECURSIVE_LOCKS != 0
2026  if (pthread_mutexattr_settype(&attr, PTHREAD_MUTEX_RECURSIVE)) return 1;
2027 #endif
2028  if (pthread_mutex_init(lk, &attr)) return 1;
2029  if (pthread_mutexattr_destroy(&attr)) return 1;
2030  return 0;
2031 }
2032 
2033 #endif /* ... lock types ... */

2040 #endif
