2047 
2048 /* ----------------------- Chunk representations ------------------------ */
2049 
2050 /*
2051  (The following includes lightly edited explanations by Colin Plumb.)
2052 
2053  The malloc_chunk declaration below is misleading (but accurate and
2054  necessary). It declares a "view" into memory allowing access to
2055  necessary fields at known offsets from a given base.
2056 
2057  Chunks of memory are maintained using a `boundary tag' method as
2058  originally described by Knuth. (See the paper by Paul Wilson
2059  ftp://ftp.cs.utexas.edu/pub/garbage/allocsrv.ps for a survey of such
2060  techniques.) Sizes of free chunks are stored both in the front of
2061  each chunk and at the end. This makes consolidating fragmented
2062  chunks into bigger chunks fast. The head fields also hold bits
2063  representing whether chunks are free or in use.
2064 
2065  Here are some pictures to make it clearer. They are "exploded" to
2066  show that the state of a chunk can be thought of as extending from
2067  the high 31 bits of the head field of its header through the
2068  prev_foot and PINUSE_BIT bit of the following chunk header.
2069 
2070  A chunk that's in use looks like:
2071 
2072  chunk-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2073  | Size of previous chunk (if P = 0) |
2074  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2075  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+ |P|
2076  | Size of this chunk 1| +-+
2077  mem-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2078  | |
2079  +- -+
2080  | |
2081  +- -+
2082  | :
2083  +- size - sizeof(size_t) available payload bytes -+
2084  : |
2085  chunk-> +- -+
2086  | |
2087  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2088  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+ |1|
2089  | Size of next chunk (may or may not be in use) | +-+
2090  mem-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2091 
2092  And if it's free, it looks like this:
2093 
2094  chunk-> +- -+
2095  | User payload (must be in use, or we would have merged!) |
2096  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2097  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+ |P|
2098  | Size of this chunk 0| +-+
2099  mem-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2100  | Next pointer |
2101  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2102  | Prev pointer |
2103  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2104  | :
2105  +- size - sizeof(struct chunk) unused bytes -+
2106  : |
2107  chunk-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2108  | Size of this chunk |
2109  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2110  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+ |0|
2111  | Size of next chunk (must be in use, or we would have merged)| +-+
2112  mem-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2113  | :
2114  +- User payload -+
2115  : |
2116  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2117  |0|
2118  +-+
2119  Note that since we always merge adjacent free chunks, the chunks
2120  adjacent to a free chunk must be in use.
2121 
2122  Given a pointer to a chunk (which can be derived trivially from the
2123  payload pointer) we can, in O(1) time, find out whether the adjacent
2124  chunks are free, and if so, unlink them from the lists that they
2125  are on and merge them with the current chunk.
2126 
2127  Chunks always begin on even word boundaries, so the mem portion
2128  (which is returned to the user) is also on an even word boundary, and
2129  thus at least double-word aligned.
2130 
2131  The P (PINUSE_BIT) bit, stored in the unused low-order bit of the
2132  chunk size (which is always a multiple of two words), is an in-use
2133  bit for the *previous* chunk. If that bit is *clear*, then the
2134  word before the current chunk size contains the previous chunk
2135  size, and can be used to find the front of the previous chunk.
2136  The very first chunk allocated always has this bit set, preventing
2137  access to non-existent (or non-owned) memory. If pinuse is set for
2138  any given chunk, then you CANNOT determine the size of the
2139  previous chunk, and might even get a memory addressing fault when
2140  trying to do so.
2141 
2142  The C (CINUSE_BIT) bit, stored in the unused second-lowest bit of
2143  the chunk size redundantly records whether the current chunk is
2144  inuse (unless the chunk is mmapped). This redundancy enables usage
2145  checks within free and realloc, and reduces indirection when freeing
2146  and consolidating chunks.
2147 
2148  Each freshly allocated chunk must have both cinuse and pinuse set.
2149  That is, each allocated chunk borders either a previously allocated
2150  and still in-use chunk, or the base of its memory arena. This is
2151  ensured by making all allocations from the `lowest' part of any
2152  found chunk. Further, no free chunk physically borders another one,
2153  so each free chunk is known to be preceded and followed by either
2154  inuse chunks or the ends of memory.
2155 
2156  Note that the `foot' of the current chunk is actually represented
2157  as the prev_foot of the NEXT chunk. This makes it easier to
2158  deal with alignments etc but can be very confusing when trying
2159  to extend or adapt this code.
2160 
2161  The exceptions to all this are
2162 
2163  1. The special chunk `top' is the top-most available chunk (i.e.,
2164  the one bordering the end of available memory). It is treated
2165  specially. Top is never included in any bin, is used only if
2166  no other chunk is available, and is released back to the
2167  system if it is very large (see M_TRIM_THRESHOLD). In effect,
2168  the top chunk is treated as larger (and thus less well
2169  fitting) than any other available chunk. The top chunk
2170  doesn't update its trailing size field since there is no next
2171  contiguous chunk that would have to index off it. However,
2172  space is still allocated for it (TOP_FOOT_SIZE) to enable
2173  separation or merging when space is extended.
2174 
2175  3. Chunks allocated via mmap, have both cinuse and pinuse bits
2176  cleared in their head fields. Because they are allocated
2177  one-by-one, each must carry its own prev_foot field, which is
2178  also used to hold the offset this chunk has within its mmapped
2179  region, which is needed to preserve alignment. Each mmapped
2180  chunk is trailed by the first two fields of a fake next-chunk
2181  for sake of usage checks.
2182 
2183 */
2184 
2185 struct malloc_chunk {
2186  size_t prev_foot; /* Size of previous chunk (if free). */
2187  size_t head; /* Size and inuse bits. */
2188  struct malloc_chunk* fd; /* double links -- used only if free. */
2189  struct malloc_chunk* bk;
2190 };
2191 
2192 typedef struct malloc_chunk mchunk;
2193 typedef struct malloc_chunk* mchunkptr;
2194 typedef struct malloc_chunk* sbinptr; /* The type of bins of chunks */
2195 typedef unsigned int bindex_t; /* Described below */
2196 typedef unsigned int binmap_t; /* Described below */
2197 typedef unsigned int flag_t; /* The type of various bit flag sets */
2198 
2199 /* ------------------- Chunks sizes and alignments ----------------------- */
2200 
2201 #define MCHUNK_SIZE (sizeof(mchunk))
2202 
2203 #if FOOTERS
2204 #define CHUNK_OVERHEAD (TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES)
2205 #else /* FOOTERS */
2206 #define CHUNK_OVERHEAD (SIZE_T_SIZE)
2207 #endif /* FOOTERS */
2208 
2209 /* MMapped chunks need a second word of overhead ... */
2210 #define MMAP_CHUNK_OVERHEAD (TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES)
2211 /* ... and additional padding for fake next-chunk at foot */
2212 #define MMAP_FOOT_PAD (FOUR_SIZE_T_SIZES)
2213 
2214 /* The smallest size we can malloc is an aligned minimal chunk */
2215 #define MIN_CHUNK_SIZE\
2216  ((MCHUNK_SIZE + CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK) & ~CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK)
2217 
2218 /* conversion from malloc headers to user pointers, and back */
2219 #define chunk2mem(p) ((void*)((char*)(p) + TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES))
2220 #define mem2chunk(mem) ((mchunkptr)((char*)(mem) - TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES))
2221 /* chunk associated with aligned address A */
2222 #define align_as_chunk(A) (mchunkptr)((A) + align_offset(chunk2mem(A)))
2223 
2224 /* Bounds on request (not chunk) sizes. */
2225 #define MAX_REQUEST ((-MIN_CHUNK_SIZE) << 2)
2226 #define MIN_REQUEST (MIN_CHUNK_SIZE - CHUNK_OVERHEAD - SIZE_T_ONE)
2227 
2228 /* pad request bytes into a usable size */
2229 #define pad_request(req) \
2230  (((req) + CHUNK_OVERHEAD + CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK) & ~CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK)
2231 
2232 /* pad request, checking for minimum (but not maximum) */
2233 #define request2size(req) \
2234  (((req) < MIN_REQUEST)? MIN_CHUNK_SIZE : pad_request(req))
2235 
2236 
2237 /* ------------------ Operations on head and foot fields ----------------- */
2238 
2239 /*
2240  The head field of a chunk is or'ed with PINUSE_BIT when previous
2241  adjacent chunk in use, and or'ed with CINUSE_BIT if this chunk is in
2242  use, unless mmapped, in which case both bits are cleared.
2243 
2244  FLAG4_BIT is not used by this malloc, but might be useful in extensions.
2245 */
2246 
2247 #define PINUSE_BIT (SIZE_T_ONE)
2248 #define CINUSE_BIT (SIZE_T_TWO)
2249 #define FLAG4_BIT (SIZE_T_FOUR)
2250 #define INUSE_BITS (PINUSE_BIT|CINUSE_BIT)
2251 #define FLAG_BITS (PINUSE_BIT|CINUSE_BIT|FLAG4_BIT)
2252 
2253 /* Head value for fenceposts */
2254 #define FENCEPOST_HEAD (INUSE_BITS|SIZE_T_SIZE)
2255 
2256 /* extraction of fields from head words */
2257 #define cinuse(p) ((p)->head & CINUSE_BIT)
2258 #define pinuse(p) ((p)->head & PINUSE_BIT)
2259 #define flag4inuse(p) ((p)->head & FLAG4_BIT)
2260 #define is_inuse(p) (((p)->head & INUSE_BITS) != PINUSE_BIT)
2261 #define is_mmapped(p) (((p)->head & INUSE_BITS) == 0)
2262 
2263 #define chunksize(p) ((p)->head & ~(FLAG_BITS))
2264 
2265 #define clear_pinuse(p) ((p)->head &= ~PINUSE_BIT)
2266 #define set_flag4(p) ((p)->head |= FLAG4_BIT)
2267 #define clear_flag4(p) ((p)->head &= ~FLAG4_BIT)
2268 
2269 /* Treat space at ptr +/- offset as a chunk */
2270 #define chunk_plus_offset(p, s) ((mchunkptr)(((char*)(p)) + (s)))
2271 #define chunk_minus_offset(p, s) ((mchunkptr)(((char*)(p)) - (s)))
2272 
2273 /* Ptr to next or previous physical malloc_chunk. */
2274 #define next_chunk(p) ((mchunkptr)( ((char*)(p)) + ((p)->head & ~FLAG_BITS)))
2275 #define prev_chunk(p) ((mchunkptr)( ((char*)(p)) - ((p)->prev_foot) ))
2276 
2277 /* extract next chunk's pinuse bit */
2278 #define next_pinuse(p) ((next_chunk(p)->head) & PINUSE_BIT)
2279 
2280 /* Get/set size at footer */
2281 #define get_foot(p, s) (((mchunkptr)((char*)(p) + (s)))->prev_foot)
2282 #define set_foot(p, s) (((mchunkptr)((char*)(p) + (s)))->prev_foot = (s))
2283 
2284 /* Set size, pinuse bit, and foot */
2285 #define set_size_and_pinuse_of_free_chunk(p, s)\
2286  ((p)->head = (s|PINUSE_BIT), set_foot(p, s))
2287 
2288 /* Set size, pinuse bit, foot, and clear next pinuse */
2289 #define set_free_with_pinuse(p, s, n)\
2290  (clear_pinuse(n), set_size_and_pinuse_of_free_chunk(p, s))
2291 
2292 /* Get the internal overhead associated with chunk p */
2293 #define overhead_for(p)\
2294  (is_mmapped(p)? MMAP_CHUNK_OVERHEAD : CHUNK_OVERHEAD)
2295 
2296 /* Return true if malloced space is not necessarily cleared */
2297 #if MMAP_CLEARS
2298 #define calloc_must_clear(p) (!is_mmapped(p))
2299 #else /* MMAP_CLEARS */
2300 #define calloc_must_clear(p) (1)
2301 #endif /* MMAP_CLEARS */
2302 
2303 /* ---------------------- Overlaid data structures ----------------------- */
2304 
2305 /*
2306  When chunks are not in use, they are treated as nodes of either
2307  lists or trees.
2308 
2309  "Small" chunks are stored in circular doubly-linked lists, and look
2310  like this:
2311 
2312  chunk-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2313  | Size of previous chunk |
2314  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2315  `head:' | Size of chunk, in bytes |P|
2316  mem-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2317  | Forward pointer to next chunk in list |
2318  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2319  | Back pointer to previous chunk in list |
2320  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2321  | Unused space (may be 0 bytes long) .
2322  . .
2323  . |
2324 nextchunk-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2325  `foot:' | Size of chunk, in bytes |
2326  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2327 
2328  Larger chunks are kept in a form of bitwise digital trees (aka
2329  tries) keyed on chunksizes. Because malloc_tree_chunks are only for
2330  free chunks greater than 256 bytes, their size doesn't impose any
2331  constraints on user chunk sizes. Each node looks like:
2332 
2333  chunk-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2334  | Size of previous chunk |
2335  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2336  `head:' | Size of chunk, in bytes |P|
2337  mem-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2338  | Forward pointer to next chunk of same size |
2339  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2340  | Back pointer to previous chunk of same size |
2341  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2342  | Pointer to left child (child[0]) |
2343  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2344  | Pointer to right child (child[1]) |
2345  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2346  | Pointer to parent |
2347  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2348  | bin index of this chunk |
2349  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2350  | Unused space .
2351  . |
2352 nextchunk-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2353  `foot:' | Size of chunk, in bytes |
2354  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
2355 
2356  Each tree holding treenodes is a tree of unique chunk sizes. Chunks
2357  of the same size are arranged in a circularly-linked list, with only
2358  the oldest chunk (the next to be used, in our FIFO ordering)
2359  actually in the tree. (Tree members are distinguished by a non-null
2360  parent pointer.) If a chunk with the same size an an existing node
2361  is inserted, it is linked off the existing node using pointers that
2362  work in the same way as fd/bk pointers of small chunks.
2363 
2364  Each tree contains a power of 2 sized range of chunk sizes (the
2365  smallest is 0x100 <= x < 0x180), which is is divided in half at each
2366  tree level, with the chunks in the smaller half of the range (0x100
2367  <= x < 0x140 for the top nose) in the left subtree and the larger
2368  half (0x140 <= x < 0x180) in the right subtree. This is, of course,
2369  done by inspecting individual bits.
2370 
2371  Using these rules, each node's left subtree contains all smaller
2372  sizes than its right subtree. However, the node at the root of each
2373  subtree has no particular ordering relationship to either. (The
2374  dividing line between the subtree sizes is based on trie relation.)
2375  If we remove the last chunk of a given size from the interior of the
2376  tree, we need to replace it with a leaf node. The tree ordering
2377  rules permit a node to be replaced by any leaf below it.
2378 
2379  The smallest chunk in a tree (a common operation in a best-fit
2380  allocator) can be found by walking a path to the leftmost leaf in
2381  the tree. Unlike a usual binary tree, where we follow left child
2382  pointers until we reach a null, here we follow the right child
2383  pointer any time the left one is null, until we reach a leaf with
2384  both child pointers null. The smallest chunk in the tree will be
2385  somewhere along that path.
2386 
2387  The worst case number of steps to add, find, or remove a node is
2388  bounded by the number of bits differentiating chunks within
2389  bins. Under current bin calculations, this ranges from 6 up to 21
2390  (for 32 bit sizes) or up to 53 (for 64 bit sizes). The typical case
2391  is of course much better.
2392 */
2393 
2394 struct malloc_tree_chunk {
2395  /* The first four fields must be compatible with malloc_chunk */
2396  size_t prev_foot;
2397  size_t head;
2398  struct malloc_tree_chunk* fd;
2399  struct malloc_tree_chunk* bk;
2400 
2401  struct malloc_tree_chunk* child[2];
2402  struct malloc_tree_chunk* parent;
2403  bindex_t index;
2404 };
2405 
2406 typedef struct malloc_tree_chunk tchunk;
2407 typedef struct malloc_tree_chunk* tchunkptr;
2408 typedef struct malloc_tree_chunk* tbinptr; /* The type of bins of trees */
2409 
2410 /* A little helper macro for trees */
2411 #define leftmost_child(t) ((t)->child[0] != 0? (t)->child[0] : (t)->child[1])
2412 
2413 /* ----------------------------- Segments -------------------------------- */
2414 
2415 /*
2416  Each malloc space may include non-contiguous segments, held in a
2417  list headed by an embedded malloc_segment record representing the
2418  top-most space. Segments also include flags holding properties of
2419  the space. Large chunks that are directly allocated by mmap are not
2420  included in this list. They are instead independently created and
2421  destroyed without otherwise keeping track of them.
2422 
2423  Segment management mainly comes into play for spaces allocated by
2424  MMAP. Any call to MMAP might or might not return memory that is
2425  adjacent to an existing segment. MORECORE normally contiguously
2426  extends the current space, so this space is almost always adjacent,
2427  which is simpler and faster to deal with. (This is why MORECORE is
2428  used preferentially to MMAP when both are available -- see
2429  sys_alloc.) When allocating using MMAP, we don't use any of the
2430  hinting mechanisms (inconsistently) supported in various
2431  implementations of unix mmap, or distinguish reserving from
2432  committing memory. Instead, we just ask for space, and exploit
2433  contiguity when we get it. It is probably possible to do
2434  better than this on some systems, but no general scheme seems
2435  to be significantly better.
2436 
2437  Management entails a simpler variant of the consolidation scheme
2438  used for chunks to reduce fragmentation -- new adjacent memory is
2439  normally prepended or appended to an existing segment. However,
2440  there are limitations compared to chunk consolidation that mostly
2441  reflect the fact that segment processing is relatively infrequent
2442  (occurring only when getting memory from system) and that we
2443  don't expect to have huge numbers of segments:
2444 
2445  * Segments are not indexed, so traversal requires linear scans. (It
2446  would be possible to index these, but is not worth the extra
2447  overhead and complexity for most programs on most platforms.)
2448  * New segments are only appended to old ones when holding top-most
2449  memory; if they cannot be prepended to others, they are held in
2450  different segments.
2451 
2452  Except for the top-most segment of an mstate, each segment record
2453  is kept at the tail of its segment. Segments are added by pushing
2454  segment records onto the list headed by &mstate.seg for the
2455  containing mstate.
2456 
2457  Segment flags control allocation/merge/deallocation policies:
2458  * If EXTERN_BIT set, then we did not allocate this segment,
2459  and so should not try to deallocate or merge with others.
2460  (This currently holds only for the initial segment passed
2461  into create_mspace_with_base.)
2462  * If USE_MMAP_BIT set, the segment may be merged with
2463  other surrounding mmapped segments and trimmed/de-allocated
2464  using munmap.
2465  * If neither bit is set, then the segment was obtained using
2466  MORECORE so can be merged with surrounding MORECORE'd segments
2467  and deallocated/trimmed using MORECORE with negative arguments.
2468 */
2469 
2470 struct malloc_segment {
2471  char* base; /* base address */
2472  size_t size; /* allocated size */
2473  struct malloc_segment* next; /* ptr to next segment */
2474  flag_t sflags; /* mmap and extern flag */
2475 };
2476 
2477 #define is_mmapped_segment(S) ((S)->sflags & USE_MMAP_BIT)
2478 #define is_extern_segment(S) ((S)->sflags & EXTERN_BIT)
2479 
2480 typedef struct malloc_segment msegment;
2481 typedef struct malloc_segment* msegmentptr;
2482 
2483 /* ---------------------------- malloc_state ----------------------------- */
2484 
2485 /*
2486  A malloc_state holds all of the bookkeeping for a space.
2487  The main fields are:
2488 
2489  Top
2490  The topmost chunk of the currently active segment. Its size is
2491  cached in topsize. The actual size of topmost space is
2492  topsize+TOP_FOOT_SIZE, which includes space reserved for adding
2493  fenceposts and segment records if necessary when getting more
2494  space from the system. The size at which to autotrim top is
2495  cached from mparams in trim_check, except that it is disabled if
2496  an autotrim fails.
2497 
2498  Designated victim (dv)
2499  This is the preferred chunk for servicing small requests that
2500  don't have exact fits. It is normally the chunk split off most
2501  recently to service another small request. Its size is cached in
2502  dvsize. The link fields of this chunk are not maintained since it
2503  is not kept in a bin.
2504 
2505  SmallBins
2506  An array of bin headers for free chunks. These bins hold chunks
2507  with sizes less than MIN_LARGE_SIZE bytes. Each bin contains
2508  chunks of all the same size, spaced 8 bytes apart. To simplify
2509  use in double-linked lists, each bin header acts as a malloc_chunk
2510  pointing to the real first node, if it exists (else pointing to
2511  itself). This avoids special-casing for headers. But to avoid
2512  waste, we allocate only the fd/bk pointers of bins, and then use
2513  repositioning tricks to treat these as the fields of a chunk.
2514 
2515  TreeBins
2516  Treebins are pointers to the roots of trees holding a range of
2517  sizes. There are 2 equally spaced treebins for each power of two
2518  from TREE_SHIFT to TREE_SHIFT+16. The last bin holds anything
2519  larger.
2520 
2521  Bin maps
2522  There is one bit map for small bins ("smallmap") and one for
2523  treebins ("treemap). Each bin sets its bit when non-empty, and
2524  clears the bit when empty. Bit operations are then used to avoid
2525  bin-by-bin searching -- nearly all "search" is done without ever
2526  looking at bins that won't be selected. The bit maps
2527  conservatively use 32 bits per map word, even if on 64bit system.
2528  For a good description of some of the bit-based techniques used
2529  here, see Henry S. Warren Jr's book "Hacker's Delight" (and
2530  supplement at http://hackersdelight.org/). Many of these are
2531  intended to reduce the branchiness of paths through malloc etc, as
2532  well as to reduce the number of memory locations read or written.
2533 
2534  Segments
2535  A list of segments headed by an embedded malloc_segment record
2536  representing the initial space.
2537 
2538  Address check support
2539  The least_addr field is the least address ever obtained from
2540  MORECORE or MMAP. Attempted frees and reallocs of any address less
2541  than this are trapped (unless INSECURE is defined).
2542 
2543  Magic tag
2544  A cross-check field that should always hold same value as mparams.magic.
2545 
2546  Max allowed footprint
2547  The maximum allowed bytes to allocate from system (zero means no limit)
2548 
2549  Flags
2550  Bits recording whether to use MMAP, locks, or contiguous MORECORE
2551 
2552  Statistics
2553  Each space keeps track of current and maximum system memory
2554  obtained via MORECORE or MMAP.
2555 
2556  Trim support
2557  Fields holding the amount of unused topmost memory that should trigger
2558  trimming, and a counter to force periodic scanning to release unused
2559  non-topmost segments.
2560 
2561  Locking
2562  If USE_LOCKS is defined, the "mutex" lock is acquired and released
2563  around every public call using this mspace.
2564 
2565  Extension support
2566  A void* pointer and a size_t field that can be used to help implement
2567  extensions to this malloc.
2568 */
2569 
2570 /* Bin types, widths and sizes */
2571 #define NSMALLBINS (32U)
2572 #define NTREEBINS (32U)
2573 #define SMALLBIN_SHIFT (3U)
2574 #define SMALLBIN_WIDTH (SIZE_T_ONE << SMALLBIN_SHIFT)
2575 #define TREEBIN_SHIFT (8U)
2576 #define MIN_LARGE_SIZE (SIZE_T_ONE << TREEBIN_SHIFT)
2577 #define MAX_SMALL_SIZE (MIN_LARGE_SIZE - SIZE_T_ONE)
2578 #define MAX_SMALL_REQUEST (MAX_SMALL_SIZE - CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK - CHUNK_OVERHEAD)
2579 
2580 struct malloc_state {
2581  binmap_t smallmap;
2582  binmap_t treemap;
2583  size_t dvsize;
2584  size_t topsize;
2585  char* least_addr;
2586  mchunkptr dv;
2587  mchunkptr top;
2588  size_t trim_check;
2589  size_t release_checks;
2590  size_t magic;
2591  mchunkptr smallbins[(NSMALLBINS+1)*2];
2592  tbinptr treebins[NTREEBINS];
2593  size_t footprint;
2594  size_t max_footprint;
2595  size_t footprint_limit; /* zero means no limit */
2596  flag_t mflags;
2597 #if USE_LOCKS
2598  MLOCK_T mutex; /* locate lock among fields that rarely change */
2599 #endif /* USE_LOCKS */
2600  msegment seg;
2601  void* extp; /* Unused but available for extensions */
2602  size_t exts;
2603 };
2604 
2605 typedef struct malloc_state* mstate;
2606

2610  malloc_params holds global properties, including those that can be
2611  dynamically set using mallopt. There is a single instance, mparams,
2612  initialized in init_mparams. Note that the non-zeroness of "magic"
2613  also serves as an initialization flag.
2614 */
2615

2649 #else

2669 /* page-align a size */

2671  (((S) + (mparams.page_size - SIZE_T_ONE)) & ~(mparams.page_size - SIZE_T_ONE))
2672

2676  & ~(mparams.granularity - SIZE_T_ONE))
2677

2679 /* For mmap, use granularity alignment on windows, else page-align */

2682 #else

2684 #endif

2686 /* For sys_alloc, enough padding to ensure can malloc request on success */
2687 #define SYS_ALLOC_PADDING (TOP_FOOT_SIZE + MALLOC_ALIGNMENT)
2688

2690  (((size_t)(S) & (mparams.page_size - SIZE_T_ONE)) == 0)
2691 #define is_granularity_aligned(S)\
2692  (((size_t)(S) & (mparams.granularity - SIZE_T_ONE)) == 0)
2693 
2694 /* True if segment S holds address A */
2695 #define segment_holds(S, A)\
2696  ((char*)(A) >= S->base && (char*)(A) < S->base + S->size)
2697 
2698 /* Return segment holding given address */
2699 static msegmentptr segment_holding(mstate m, char* addr) {
2700  msegmentptr sp = &m->seg;
2701  for (;;) {
2702  if (addr >= sp->base && addr < sp->base + sp->size)
2703  return sp;
2704  if ((sp = sp->next) == 0)
2705  return 0;
2706  }
2707 }
2708 
2709 /* Return true if segment contains a segment link */
2710 static int has_segment_link(mstate m, msegmentptr ss) {
2711  msegmentptr sp = &m->seg;
2712  for (;;) {
2713  if ((char*)sp >= ss->base && (char*)sp < ss->base + ss->size)
2714  return 1;
2715  if ((sp = sp->next) == 0)
2716  return 0;
2717  }
2718 }
2719 
2720 #ifndef MORECORE_CANNOT_TRIM
2721 #define should_trim(M,s) ((s) > (M)->trim_check)
2722 #else /* MORECORE_CANNOT_TRIM */
2723 #define should_trim(M,s) (0)
2724 #endif /* MORECORE_CANNOT_TRIM */

2726 /*
2727  TOP_FOOT_SIZE is padding at the end of a segment, including space
2728  that may be needed to place segment records and fenceposts when new
2729  noncontiguous segments are added.
2730 */
2731 #define TOP_FOOT_SIZE\
2732  (align_offset(chunk2mem(0))+pad_request(sizeof(struct malloc_segment))+MIN_CHUNK_SIZE)

2738  PREACTION should be defined to return 0 on success, and nonzero on
2739  failure. If you are not using locking, you can redefine these to do
2740  anything you like.

2742

2745 #define POSTACTION(M) { if (use_lock(M)) RELEASE_LOCK(&(M)->mutex); }
2746 #else /* USE_LOCKS */

2748 #ifndef PREACTION

2751

2754 #endif /* POSTACTION */
2755 
2756 #endif /* USE_LOCKS */

2760  USAGE_ERROR_ACTION is triggered on detected bad frees and
2761  reallocs. The argument p is an address that might have triggered the
2762  fault. It is ignored by the two predefined actions, but might be
2763  useful in custom actions that try to help diagnose errors.
2764 */

2775 #define USAGE_ERROR_ACTION(m, p)
2776 
2777 #else /* PROCEED_ON_ERROR */

2781 #endif /* CORRUPTION_ERROR_ACTION */
2782 
2783 #ifndef USAGE_ERROR_ACTION

2785 #endif /* USAGE_ERROR_ACTION */

2823 /* ---------------------------- Indexing Bins ---------------------------- */
2824 
2825 #define is_small(s) (((s) >> SMALLBIN_SHIFT) < NSMALLBINS)
2826 #define small_index(s) (bindex_t)((s) >> SMALLBIN_SHIFT)
2827 #define small_index2size(i) ((i) << SMALLBIN_SHIFT)
2828 #define MIN_SMALL_INDEX (small_index(MIN_CHUNK_SIZE))
2829 
2830 /* addressing by index. See above about smallbin repositioning */
2831 #define smallbin_at(M, i) ((sbinptr)((char*)&((M)->smallbins[(i)<<1])))
2832 #define treebin_at(M,i) (&((M)->treebins[i]))
2833 
2834 /* assign tree index for size S to variable I. Use x86 asm if possible */
2835 #if defined(__GNUC__) && (defined(__i386__) || defined(__x86_64__))
2836 #define compute_tree_index(S, I)\
2837 {\
2838  unsigned int X = S >> TREEBIN_SHIFT;\
2839  if (X == 0)\
2840  I = 0;\
2841  else if (X > 0xFFFF)\
2842  I = NTREEBINS-1;\
2843  else {\
2844  unsigned int K = (unsigned) sizeof(X)*__CHAR_BIT__ - 1 - (unsigned) __builtin_clz(X); \
2845  I = (bindex_t)((K << 1) + ((S >> (K + (TREEBIN_SHIFT-1)) & 1)));\
2846  }\
2847 }
2848 
2849 #elif defined (__INTEL_COMPILER)
2850 #define compute_tree_index(S, I)\
2851 {\
2852  size_t X = S >> TREEBIN_SHIFT;\
2853  if (X == 0)\
2854  I = 0;\
2855  else if (X > 0xFFFF)\
2856  I = NTREEBINS-1;\
2857  else {\
2858  unsigned int K = _bit_scan_reverse (X); \
2859  I = (bindex_t)((K << 1) + ((S >> (K + (TREEBIN_SHIFT-1)) & 1)));\
2860  }\
2861 }
2862 
2863 #elif defined(_MSC_VER) && _MSC_VER>=1300
2864 #define compute_tree_index(S, I)\
2865 {\
2866  size_t X = S >> TREEBIN_SHIFT;\
2867  if (X == 0)\
2868  I = 0;\
2869  else if (X > 0xFFFF)\
2870  I = NTREEBINS-1;\
2871  else {\
2872  unsigned int K;\
2873  _BitScanReverse((DWORD *) &K, (DWORD) X);\
2874  I = (bindex_t)((K << 1) + ((S >> (K + (TREEBIN_SHIFT-1)) & 1)));\
2875  }\
2876 }
2877 
2878 #else /* GNUC */
2879 #define compute_tree_index(S, I)\
2880 {\
2881  size_t X = S >> TREEBIN_SHIFT;\
2882  if (X == 0)\
2883  I = 0;\
2884  else if (X > 0xFFFF)\
2885  I = NTREEBINS-1;\
2886  else {\
2887  unsigned int Y = (unsigned int)X;\
2888  unsigned int N = ((Y - 0x100) >> 16) & 8;\
2889  unsigned int K = (((Y <<= N) - 0x1000) >> 16) & 4;\
2890  N += K;\
2891  N += K = (((Y <<= K) - 0x4000) >> 16) & 2;\
2892  K = 14 - N + ((Y <<= K) >> 15);\
2893  I = (K << 1) + ((S >> (K + (TREEBIN_SHIFT-1)) & 1));\
2894  }\
2895 }
2896 #endif /* GNUC */
2897 
2898 /* Bit representing maximum resolved size in a treebin at i */
2899 #define bit_for_tree_index(i) \
2900  (i == NTREEBINS-1)? (SIZE_T_BITSIZE-1) : (((i) >> 1) + TREEBIN_SHIFT - 2)
2901 
2902 /* Shift placing maximum resolved bit in a treebin at i as sign bit */
2903 #define leftshift_for_tree_index(i) \
2904  ((i == NTREEBINS-1)? 0 : \
2905  ((SIZE_T_BITSIZE-SIZE_T_ONE) - (((i) >> 1) + TREEBIN_SHIFT - 2)))
2906 
2907 /* The size of the smallest chunk held in bin with index i */
2908 #define minsize_for_tree_index(i) \
2909  ((SIZE_T_ONE << (((i) >> 1) + TREEBIN_SHIFT)) | \
2910  (((size_t)((i) & SIZE_T_ONE)) << (((i) >> 1) + TREEBIN_SHIFT - 1)))
2911

2913 /* ------------------------ Operations on bin maps ----------------------- */
2914 
2915 /* bit corresponding to given index */
2916 #define idx2bit(i) ((binmap_t)(1) << (i))
2917 
2918 /* Mark/Clear bits with given index */
2919 #define mark_smallmap(M,i) ((M)->smallmap |= idx2bit(i))
2920 #define clear_smallmap(M,i) ((M)->smallmap &= ~idx2bit(i))
2921 #define smallmap_is_marked(M,i) ((M)->smallmap & idx2bit(i))
2922 
2923 #define mark_treemap(M,i) ((M)->treemap |= idx2bit(i))
2924 #define clear_treemap(M,i) ((M)->treemap &= ~idx2bit(i))
2925 #define treemap_is_marked(M,i) ((M)->treemap & idx2bit(i))
2926 
2927 /* isolate the least set bit of a bitmap */
2928 #define least_bit(x) ((x) & -(x))
2929 
2930 /* mask with all bits to left of least bit of x on */
2931 #define left_bits(x) ((x<<1) | -(x<<1))
2932 
2933 /* mask with all bits to left of or equal to least bit of x on */
2934 #define same_or_left_bits(x) ((x) | -(x))
2935 
2936 /* index corresponding to given bit. Use x86 asm if possible */
2937 
2938 #if defined(__GNUC__) && (defined(__i386__) || defined(__x86_64__))
2939 #define compute_bit2idx(X, I)\
2940 {\
2941  unsigned int J;\
2942  J = __builtin_ctz(X); \
2943  I = (bindex_t)J;\
2944 }
2945 
2946 #elif defined (__INTEL_COMPILER)
2947 #define compute_bit2idx(X, I)\
2948 {\
2949  unsigned int J;\
2950  J = _bit_scan_forward (X); \
2951  I = (bindex_t)J;\
2952 }
2953 
2954 #elif defined(_MSC_VER) && _MSC_VER>=1300
2955 #define compute_bit2idx(X, I)\
2956 {\
2957  unsigned int J;\
2958  _BitScanForward((DWORD *) &J, X);\
2959  I = (bindex_t)J;\
2960 }
2961 
2962 #elif USE_BUILTIN_FFS
2963 #define compute_bit2idx(X, I) I = ffs(X)-1
2964 
2965 #else
2966 #define compute_bit2idx(X, I)\
2967 {\
2968  unsigned int Y = X - 1;\
2969  unsigned int K = Y >> (16-4) & 16;\
2970  unsigned int N = K; Y >>= K;\
2971  N += K = Y >> (8-3) & 8; Y >>= K;\
2972  N += K = Y >> (4-2) & 4; Y >>= K;\
2973  N += K = Y >> (2-1) & 2; Y >>= K;\
2974  N += K = Y >> (1-0) & 1; Y >>= K;\
2975  I = (bindex_t)(N + Y);\
2976 }
2977 #endif /* GNUC */
2978 
2979 
2980 /* ----------------------- Runtime Check Support ------------------------- */
2981 
2982 /*
2983  For security, the main invariant is that malloc/free/etc never
2984  writes to a static address other than malloc_state, unless static
2985  malloc_state itself has been corrupted, which cannot occur via
2986  malloc (because of these checks). In essence this means that we
2987  believe all pointers, sizes, maps etc held in malloc_state, but
2988  check all of those linked or offsetted from other embedded data
2989  structures. These checks are interspersed with main code in a way
2990  that tends to minimize their run-time cost.
2991 
2992  When FOOTERS is defined, in addition to range checking, we also
2993  verify footer fields of inuse chunks, which can be used guarantee
2994  that the mstate controlling malloc/free is intact. This is a
2995  streamlined version of the approach described by William Robertson
2996  et al in "Run-time Detection of Heap-based Overflows" LISA'03
2997  http://www.usenix.org/events/lisa03/tech/robertson.html The footer
2998  of an inuse chunk holds the xor of its mstate and a random seed,
2999  that is checked upon calls to free() and realloc(). This is
3000  (probabalistically) unguessable from outside the program, but can be
3001  computed by any code successfully malloc'ing any chunk, so does not
3002  itself provide protection against code that has already broken
3003  security through some other means. Unlike Robertson et al, we
3004  always dynamically check addresses of all offset chunks (previous,
3005  next, etc). This turns out to be cheaper than relying on hashes.
3006 */
3007 
3008 #if !INSECURE
3009 /* Check if address a is at least as high as any from MORECORE or MMAP */
3010 #define ok_address(M, a) ((char*)(a) >= (M)->least_addr)
3011 /* Check if address of next chunk n is higher than base chunk p */
3012 #define ok_next(p, n) ((char*)(p) < (char*)(n))
3013 /* Check if p has inuse status */
3014 #define ok_inuse(p) is_inuse(p)
3015 /* Check if p has its pinuse bit on */
3016 #define ok_pinuse(p) pinuse(p)
3017 
3018 #else /* !INSECURE */
3019 #define ok_address(M, a) (1)
3020 #define ok_next(b, n) (1)
3021 #define ok_inuse(p) (1)
3022 #define ok_pinuse(p) (1)
3023 #endif /* !INSECURE */
3024 
3025 #if (FOOTERS && !INSECURE)
3026 /* Check if (alleged) mstate m has expected magic field */
3027 #define ok_magic(M) ((M)->magic == mparams.magic)
3028 #else /* (FOOTERS && !INSECURE) */
3029 #define ok_magic(M) (1)
3030 #endif /* (FOOTERS && !INSECURE) */
3031 
3032 /* In gcc, use __builtin_expect to minimize impact of checks */
3033 #if !INSECURE
3034 #if defined(__GNUC__) && __GNUC__ >= 3
3035 #define RTCHECK(e) __builtin_expect(e, 1)
3036 #else /* GNUC */
3037 #define RTCHECK(e) (e)
3038 #endif /* GNUC */
3039 #else /* !INSECURE */
3040 #define RTCHECK(e) (1)
3041 #endif /* !INSECURE */

3043 /* macros to set up inuse chunks with or without footers */

3047 #define mark_inuse_foot(M,p,s)

3060

3064 
3065 #else /* FOOTERS */

3068 #define mark_inuse_foot(M,p,s)\
3069  (((mchunkptr)((char*)(p) + (s)))->prev_foot = ((size_t)(M) ^ mparams.magic))
3070 
3071 #define get_mstate_for(p)\
3072  ((mstate)(((mchunkptr)((char*)(p) +\
3073  (chunksize(p))))->prev_foot ^ mparams.magic))
3074 
3075 #define set_inuse(M,p,s)\
3076  ((p)->head = (((p)->head & PINUSE_BIT)|s|CINUSE_BIT),\
3077  (((mchunkptr)(((char*)(p)) + (s)))->head |= PINUSE_BIT), \
3078  mark_inuse_foot(M,p,s))
3079 
3080 #define set_inuse_and_pinuse(M,p,s)\

3093 #if LOCK_AT_FORK
3094 static void pre_fork(void) { ACQUIRE_LOCK(&(gm)->mutex); }
3095 static void post_fork_parent(void) { RELEASE_LOCK(&(gm)->mutex); }
3096 static void post_fork_child(void) { INITIAL_LOCK(&(gm)->mutex); }

3099 /* Initialize mparams */
3100 static int init_mparams(void) {
3101 #ifdef NEED_GLOBAL_LOCK_INIT
3102  if (malloc_global_mutex_status <= 0)
3103  init_malloc_global_mutex();
3104 #endif
3105 
3106  ACQUIRE_MALLOC_GLOBAL_LOCK();
3107  if (mparams.magic == 0) {
3108  size_t magic;
3109  size_t psize;
3110  size_t gsize;
3111 
3112 #ifndef WIN32
3113  psize = malloc_getpagesize;
3114  gsize = ((DEFAULT_GRANULARITY != 0)? DEFAULT_GRANULARITY : psize);
3115 #else /* WIN32 */
3116  {
3117  SYSTEM_INFO system_info;
3118  GetSystemInfo(&system_info);
3119  psize = system_info.dwPageSize;
3120  gsize = ((DEFAULT_GRANULARITY != 0)?
3121  DEFAULT_GRANULARITY : system_info.dwAllocationGranularity);
3122  }
3123 #endif /* WIN32 */
3124 
3125  /* Sanity-check configuration:
3126  size_t must be unsigned and as wide as pointer type.
3127  ints must be at least 4 bytes.
3128  alignment must be at least 8.
3129  Alignment, min chunk size, and page size must all be powers of 2.
3130  */
3131  if ((sizeof(size_t) != sizeof(char*)) ||
3132  (MAX_SIZE_T < MIN_CHUNK_SIZE) ||
3133  (sizeof(int) < 4) ||
3134  (MALLOC_ALIGNMENT < (size_t)8U) ||
3135  ((MALLOC_ALIGNMENT & (MALLOC_ALIGNMENT-SIZE_T_ONE)) != 0) ||
3136  ((MCHUNK_SIZE & (MCHUNK_SIZE-SIZE_T_ONE)) != 0) ||
3137  ((gsize & (gsize-SIZE_T_ONE)) != 0) ||
3138  ((psize & (psize-SIZE_T_ONE)) != 0))
3139  ABORT;
3140  mparams.granularity = gsize;
3141  mparams.page_size = psize;
3142  mparams.mmap_threshold = DEFAULT_MMAP_THRESHOLD;
3143  mparams.trim_threshold = DEFAULT_TRIM_THRESHOLD;
3144 #if MORECORE_CONTIGUOUS
3145  mparams.default_mflags = USE_LOCK_BIT|USE_MMAP_BIT;
3146 #else /* MORECORE_CONTIGUOUS */
3147  mparams.default_mflags = USE_LOCK_BIT|USE_MMAP_BIT|USE_NONCONTIGUOUS_BIT;
3148 #endif /* MORECORE_CONTIGUOUS */
3149 
3150 #if !ONLY_MSPACES
3151  /* Set up lock for main malloc area */
3152  gm->mflags = mparams.default_mflags;
3153  (void)INITIAL_LOCK(&gm->mutex);
3154 #endif
3155 #if LOCK_AT_FORK
3156  pthread_atfork(&pre_fork, &post_fork_parent, &post_fork_child);
3157 #endif
3158 
3159  {
3160 #if USE_DEV_RANDOM
3161  int fd;
3162  unsigned char buf[sizeof(size_t)];
3163  /* Try to use /dev/urandom, else fall back on using time */
3164  if ((fd = open("/dev/urandom", O_RDONLY)) >= 0 &&
3165  read(fd, buf, sizeof(buf)) == sizeof(buf)) {
3166  magic = *((size_t *) buf);
3167  close(fd);
3168  }
3169  else
3170 #endif /* USE_DEV_RANDOM */
3171 #ifdef WIN32
3172  magic = (size_t)(GetTickCount() ^ (size_t)0x55555555U);
3173 #elif defined(LACKS_TIME_H)
3174  magic = (size_t)&magic ^ (size_t)0x55555555U;
3175 #else
3176  magic = (size_t)(time(0) ^ (size_t)0x55555555U);
3177 #endif
3178  magic |= (size_t)8U; /* ensure nonzero */
3179  magic &= ~(size_t)7U; /* improve chances of fault for bad values */
3180  /* Until memory modes commonly available, use volatile-write */
3181  (*(volatile size_t *)(&(mparams.magic))) = magic;
3182  }
3183  }
3184 
3185  RELEASE_MALLOC_GLOBAL_LOCK();
3186  return 1;
3187 }
3188 
3189 /* support for mallopt */
3190 static int change_mparam(int param_number, int value) {
3191  size_t val;
3192  ensure_initialization();
3193  val = (value == -1)? MAX_SIZE_T : (size_t)value;
3194  switch(param_number) {
3195  case M_TRIM_THRESHOLD:
3196  mparams.trim_threshold = val;
3197  return 1;
3198  case M_GRANULARITY:
3199  if (val >= mparams.page_size && ((val & (val-1)) == 0)) {
3200  mparams.granularity = val;
3201  return 1;
3202  }
3203  else
3204  return 0;
3205  case M_MMAP_THRESHOLD:
3206  mparams.mmap_threshold = val;
3207  return 1;
3208  default:
3209  return 0;
3210  }
3211 }
